TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Breeders' Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the prospect of any legislation regarding Plant Variety Rights.
1. We believe it would transfer control, the key aspect of agriculture in this country, to overseas interests not responsible to the Australian Government.
2. We believe it would restrict the growing and trading of many seeds.
3. We believe it would cause a decline in the genetic diversity of crops making them more subject to destruction by pests and diseases.
4. We believe thorough investigation of the effect of similar legislation overseas and a full public debate is required before any decision is made.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that Parliament refrains from enacting any legislation on Plant Variety Rights.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Patients' Medical Records
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we are gravely concerned by the invasion of privacy caused by Government agents seizing patients' medical records:
Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should-
Legislate to protect the private and confidential nature of medical records from scrutiny except on the express and informed consent of the patient or an order from a presiding judge.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Were meetings of the Ministerial Committee on Public Information attended by the Federal Director of the Liberal Party, Mr Eggleton, as reported in yesterday's Age? At these meetings was Mr Eggleton able to obtain information about market research and advertising not available to other political parties? Did Mr Eggleton, at any time, suggest a line of briefing for market research companies engaged on any Government project? Did the Committee deal with Government funded projects which led to commissions for the Liberal Party advertising agency, D'Arcy-McManus and Masius Pty Ltd, or for the Party's polling organisations, Morgan Gallup or Task Quantum? Was the information derived in the course of Government work by these polling companies given to Mr Eggleton?

—Although I am a member of a Government public information committee, I am not aware of any such meeting, although a meeting could have occurred without my presence. Therefore I will refer the substance of the question to the Chairman of the Committee and seek information from him.

—My question is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy and refers to what I will call and affirm to be the River Murray crisis. Does the Minister recall the major recommendation of the Senate Select Committee on Water Pollution of some 10 years ago that as a matter of urgency a national water commission be established? Will he examine that recommendation and note both its constitutional and Federal concept? Is he aware that these recommendations are reinforced by contemporary findings of the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment? Will he acknowledge the value of these statements and persuade the Government either to heed them or to take steps to give some immediate authority to the existing and, as it was described in the Adelaide Advertiser, toothless River Murray Commission? Will he give an assurance that the nation will be spared yet another time consuming inquiry and that the Murray system will be treated as being as important to Australia as, for example, the energy situation with its present emphasis?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter raised in the question, of course, is very important. Primarily it is important to South Australia which is downstream of the confluence of the Murray and Darling rivers, but also it is of importance to the other sharing States of New South Wales and Victoria. As to the first part of the question, yes I am aware of the previous Senate report and of its significance. I will obtain a further copy of it and put it under further study. I am also aware of its recommendations and that a subsequent committee on science and the environment reinforced certain of these conclusions. The States and the Commonwealth are currently in full discussion to obtain a complete redrafting of an agreement on the River Murray. There are now only two matters in dispute. We are endeavouring to hasten their resolution. I do not believe that the Commission report is toothless. Of course, one would like to have more capacity to enforce certain matters, but in a federation what is required in terms of progress is a consensus.

ANSWER.PARA: I believe that our ability to determine at any time any potential significant changes in the flow of these river systems, by way of quantity or quality, will bring about a sufficiency of exposure to enable the right amount of dialogue for the appropriate action to be taken. If other reforms are necessary along the journey, we will put them under study. I acknowledge on behalf of the Government the importance of the River Murray, including the importance of the increased salinity aggravated by the drought, particularly in the Darling area. I am aware of the Maunsell report. All these things are under study. We intend to act upon them.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to Senator Carrick both in his capacity as Leader of the Government in the Senate and in his capacity as Minister representing the Prime Minister. I ask whether it is the case that until late last year there existed a special committee of Cabinet-known as the Intelligence and Security Committee-the functions of which were described, for example, in the Prime Minister's Press release of 4 February 1979 as being:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . to set overall policy and oversee the work of the intelligence community.

I ask whether it is the case that, following the Prime Minister's announcement of a new Cabinet committee structure on 25 November 1980, that Committee has now disappeared except insofar as the Foreign Affairs and Defence Committee is now described as existing:
. . . to consider matters concerned with international relations, defence, intelligence and security.

Is it thus the case that there is no Cabinet committee charged with the detailed oversight of security organisations and that the detailed supervision and control of such bodies is now effectively in the hands of the Prime Minister alone? Finally, I ask: To what extent is this development linked, if not with the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation's newly identified status as a creation of the KGB, then at least with the new and apparently even more sensitive functions now being exercised by the Australian Security Intelligence Service-ASIS-following Mr Justice Hope's recently revealed recommendations?

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that Senator Evans has stated the facts in regard to the earlier Intelligence and Security Committee. Today its essential functions are absorbed in the Foreign Affairs and Defence Committee of Cabinet. That Committee, in conjunction with the Prime Minister and in association with the Attorney-General, would have a primary responsibility in regard to security. I do not believe that the oversight by Cabinet of security has been weakened in any way. On the contrary, the Prime Minister has laid great stress upon the need for full intelligence and security understanding. I see no weakening at all on this matter. Indeed, I believe that the present arrangements give a full oversight.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. If there is no change in the degree of oversight that is exercised by the new Committee, why has the language of its terms of reference changed and why is there no longer a specific reference to an oversight function?
—The language used and the description of the Committee are matters for the Prime Minister. I will refer that question to him for an answer.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to the recent decision of the Reagan Administration to lift the ban on sales of military equipment to Argentina and to move away from the United States of America's previous emphasis on human rights in dealing with Argentina and other South American countries. I ask the Minister to comment on the statement of the State Department spokesman, Mr William Dyess, that the abnormality in United States-Argentine relations was due in large part to the Carter Administration's outspoken position on human affairs and that future criticism of human rights violations in authoritarian but friendly countries such as Argentina would be conducted in private. In view of the prompt, vigorous and commendable actions taken and representations made by the former Australian Minister for Foreign Affairs to Argentina and other South American countries on many human rights issues, can the Senate be assured that the Australian Government has no intention of varying its policy and attitudes to suit the convenience of these authoritarian regimes?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — It was made clear to the Minister for Foreign Affairs when he was in Washington that the United States of America is not downgrading its concern for human rights. The Secretary of State told him that the new Administration was as sensitive to human rights issues as any previous administration had been but it believed that human rights concerns were best pursued in private through diplomatic channels rather than in public. He said that, however unpleasant some of the authoritarian regimes of the Right may be, there was no point in undermining them publicly on human rights grounds to the point where they would be replaced by even more repressive totalitarian regimes of the Left. Our own commitment to international action to protect and promote human rights remains firm. We will continue to use opportunities which present themselves both privately, with governments, and through bodies such as the United Nations Commission on Human Rights to make our concerns known.

—My question, which also concerns human rights, is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I draw the Minister's attention to the grisly and appalling photograph on the front page of the Age of 21 March which depicts the sulphuric acid-caused wounds of one of the El Salvadoran Government's torture victims. Is the Minister aware that such Government-approved torture of political prisoners is part of the daily life of El Salvador? Does the Minister not agree that it is both pathetic and farcical for El Salvadoran junta leaders such as Jose Antonio Morales to deny the existence of Government-sponsored torture in the face of graphic evidence to the contrary? Does the Minister now regret the Prime Minister's statement of 5 March that the United States of America is 'entirely right' in its policy of military support for the El Salvadoran junta? Would the Minister not agree that the United States could be making the same mistake now as it did in Vietnam 20 years ago in seeking military solutions where these are not applicable? Will the Government use its close and friendly relations with the United States Administration to dissuade it from aiding the torturers and right wing death squads which are now parading in El Salvador?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not see the photograph in the Age. I will have a look at it. I am aware that suggestions have been made that there has been torture in El Salvador. Of course, the Government would reject and be thoroughly opposed to all such actions. The Government, in the expression of its attitude on El Salvador, in fact expressed precisely the viewpoint given by Senator John Wheeldon from the Opposition benches some time ago. I commend that speech to honourable senators as a good statement of the circumstances in that unhappy country. The country is in misery and has great extremes of poverty and wealth and great overcrowding. It is a country which has had oppression, which has had a change and which is now also being invaded by outside subversive elements with-as is alleged-Cuban influences. Senator Wheeldon pointed out that fact.

ANSWER.PARA: Of course, the Government does not support torture or duress at all. El Salvador is in a form of agony at this moment. A great belief in the world is that the best way to get the country out of its misery and back to a form of freedom would be to offer support to human beings to raise their living standards, to free them from the subversion that is suppressing them and to lift them upwards. I think that would be a very significant thing to do. Indeed, that view was expressed by Senator Wheeldon-an Australian Labor Party senator who was, I think, the Chairman of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence. Therefore, he must have been expressing, in his day, the viewpoints of the Labor Party of the past if not of the present.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just read Hansard.
—Mr President, I have been enjoined to read Hansard. I will do so and, when next in here, I will be happy to read the sections which, of course, confirm what I have said.

—I ask a supplementary question. I wish to ask the Minister for the views of himself and the Government and not Senator Wheeldon's views, which I respect but with which I disagree. I want the Government's views. That is the purpose of my question. I was interested to hear the Minister say that he had heard of suggestions of torture in El Salvador. I ask the Minister whether he is persuaded that government-sponsored torture does exist in El Salvador. I was pleased to hear the Minister say that the Government does not support torture in any form. How can he reconcile that forthright statement with the Prime Minister's statement that the United States is 'entirely right' in its policy of military support for the El Salvadoran junta?

—Senator Chipp, if he looks at the Hansard report of what I said, will see that I in fact indicated the Government views. I said that the Government views are in parallel with those of Senator Wheeldon and I then went on to state what those views are. Of course, the Government does not tolerate torture in any way. I am not in a position to know the facts. If Senator Chipp asked me as John Carrick I would have to say: 'Yes, I believe there is evidence that torture has occurred'. Yes, I would have to say that, and I would abhor that situation. The Government holds the view that was respectably put forward by Senator Wheeldon as a former Labor Chairman of the Joint Foreign Affairs and Defence Committee, namely, that the best way to help that unhappy country is to help it internally, through its existing systems, to lift itself up and to give itself a better living standard. The alternative is to leave the country to the communist-type subversion that has been accurately reported, I think, in terms of the Cubans and others.

—I ask a question of, I think, the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources, although it might be answered by Senator Chaney because it relates to primary industry. Is the Minister aware that in the area already proclaimed in the Kakadu National Park in the Northern Territory and in the area known as Stage 2 of that park there is possible mineralisation along a strip some 400 kilometres in length, and that to date a very small proportion of that 400-kilometre strip has been fully examined for mineralisation? Will the Minister assure the Senate that the area will be fully examined and that mining with sensible safeguards will be allowed before any further proclamations are made to enlarge that park to an area which would be over half as big as Tasmania?

—I am, of course, keenly aware of the Kakadu National Park. It is one of the exciting great national parks of the world. I am aware of Stage 1. To my knowledge, it has been asserted that there are deposits of minerals there. I am not precisely aware of where that matter stands at this moment. As to those queries, I will seek the information out and get an answer for Senator Townley.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. I draw the Minister's attention to his Press statement of Sunday, in which he stated:

QUESTION.PARA: Throughout the whole Agent Orange controversy, the Government's position had been to approach every question objectively in order to get at the true facts.

What objective or scientific survey was conducted by the Minister to enable him to conclude on Sunday that there was a growing feeling amongst some veterans that many of the social and psychological effects publicly claimed to be due to herbicides may have had their origins in war experiences in Vietnam and community attitudes on their return? What percentage of veterans did such an objective survey reveal as holding that view? Alternatively, which association or recognised body representing veterans did the Minister consult before making that statement? If he did so consult, is the statement representative of their views? Finally, which such organisations, if any, have supported the Minister's statement of Sunday?

TALK.START.PARA: —I noted the reports in the newspapers of Senator Tate's remarks following my statement on this matter to the Press on Sunday. I do not think he referred particularly to this aspect of the matter. He is seeking some information as to whether a scientific survey was undertaken in respect of my conclusion that obviously some people were affected emotionally and were in a state of anxiety as a result of publicity about agent orange. In relation to that I can give the honourable senator this information: This claim has been put to me by no less a person than the President of the Vietnam Veterans Association, Mr Holt McMinn, as a clear understanding of some of the difficulties that are faced by Vietnam veterans. Furthermore, I have personally had a number of contacts with veterans and also had calls to my office with regard to this matter. There is no doubt, in my opinion, that there is in the community a very genuine feeling that a number of veterans are having their anxieties and feelings raised above all realisation and all possibility of their ever being settled. This has come about by virtue of some sensational media coverage of this matter based on a relatively small number of cases.
—Have you seen some of the kids?

—Senator Keeffe will know, if he has been following the matter, that the Government is undertaking a most extensive survey of all 45,000 Vietnam veterans to establish whether there is any link between herbicides and the kinds of problems to which he has referred. Also a number of studies are being undertaken by the United States veterans administration, and we are anxiously awaiting that information. That does not disturb the point I am making, namely, that some cases which have been sensationalised by the media, and by politicians in some instances, have led to the sharpening and heightening of anxieties amongst some veterans to the extent that they feel that there is only one solution to their problem, and that is the herbicide matter. I believe there are other solutions to those problems and we are seeking to address ourselves to them.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The final part of the question I asked the Minister was: Which organisations, if any, representing Vietnam veterans have publicly commended or supported the Minister's statement of Sunday? In particular, has he noted representatives of any such organisations claiming that he had made assertions in that statement of Sunday which were detrimental to their cause?
—In neither case have I noted any public statements, but I have had private contacts from associations on those matters.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. I refer to an article which appeared in the West Australian of Thursday, 12 March 1981, and which was titled: 'Kanga Wine a Hit'. The article informed us that a special South Australian wine, marketed in Britain as Kanga Rouge, had been chosen as the wine of the month by the highly respected British journal Decanter. The wine is apparently a 1978 Chateau Reynella made from shiraz grapes grown at Coonawarra. Is this article true? If so, does the Government think that marketing a good quality wine with such a name makes Australia lose face in the eyes of the world wine industry? Will the Government consider asking exporters not to market Australian wine by satirical means?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable senator may have unwittingly hurt the feelings of whoever is marketing this wine; that person may not regard the name 'Kanga Rouge' as at all satirical. I am not in a position to confirm that the article is accurate although the advice I have had from the Department of Primary Industry would appear to indicate that the wine has been recognised in the way the honourable senator suggests. I am aware that some Australians hold the view that the use of colloquial names such as 'kanga' based on Australian animals and birds creates an unfavourable impression about wines. I note that you, Mr President, have avoided the temptation to put a similar name to the wine that you produce.

ANSWER.PARA: It appears that in the instant case, notwithstanding the view of the honourable senator and those of us who like something a little more along the lines of a Coonawarra or a Chateau Reynella shiraz, this wine is being marketed quite satisfactorily and no doubt any view that I express would be regarded as irrelevant by the people who are doing so. What is important is that the quality of the product from Australia is good. I think that all honourable senators will be aware that the Australian Wine Board monitors the quality of wines exported from Australia. It appears from the article referred to that the wine mentioned by the honourable senator is living up to the standards that we hope would be achieved by the Australian product. I am sure that all honourable senators will be delighted at the recognition it has achieved in the journal Decanter.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs and follows the question asked by Senator Tate. Is it not a fact that in the Minister's statement on the weekend he implied, as he implied in his answer today, that one of the problems with the Vietnam veterans and the agent orange situation is that they have insufficient knowledge of the difficulties and therefore are likely to be emotionally affected by the sort of media reports that have been forthcoming on this subject? Would it not be better for Vietnam veterans if they had more detailed knowledge of the problem? Is it not a fact that a senior officer of the Department of Veterans' Affairs has produced a very detailed study of the effects of herbicides used in Vietnam and other places? Has this report been made public? If not, why not and does the Minister intend to make this report public?

—In regard to the question about insufficient knowledge, I think it should be crystal clear to Senator Grimes that the main purpose of the epidemiological study proceeding at present is to establish whether in fact there is any link between the physical or psychological disabilities of Vietnam veterans and the use of herbicides in Vietnam. We are awaiting the result of that study. Consequently, there is that information which will establish a scientific base for any decision which the Government might need to make. Senator Grimes has referred to a report. I point out that what the honourable senator refers to is not, in fact, a report but a collection of various pieces of literature relating to herbicides and their use in Vietnam. This was referred to by the previous Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Mr Evan Adermann, in a statement at about the end of February, I believe. It was made quite public and it has been known by this Parliament and by members of the public generally that this information has been available within the Department of Veterans' Affairs. I hasten to add that the author of that report-if it can be called one; I repeat that it is a collation of various printed articles on this matter-himself acknowledges that it is not scientific evidence and would in no way supplant, be superior to or be useful to the Government in reaching its decision. In fact, the epidemiological study which is proceeding is the only basis for that.

—I wish to ask a supplementary question. Is it not a fact, as the Minister has said, that the report is a careful and scientific collection of reports from all over the world on the effects of herbicides and related products? In that case, why has the report not been made public? Would it not be useful for those assisting Vietnam veterans who believe they have been affected? Would it not assist the Vietnam veterans themselves in getting detailed information on this subject or is the problem that the articles and the report itself cast some doubt on the use and effect of herbicides in Vietnam?

—I repeat that it is not a report; it is a collation of various articles which touch on the matter of herbicides and their usages and consequently does not constitute a body of knowledge drawn in a logical fashion which can provide a basis on which a proper assessment can be made in this matter.
—Why don't you release it?

—It would not be reasonable, I believe, to release it in this case because the individual reports are in fact available to the community generally. They are available because they have been provided by the scientific adviser to the Vietnam Veterans' Association, Mr John Evans. In that case it does not seem necessary to provide that information because, as I have already said to Senator Grimes, the information is drawn in such a way as to be merely a collation. It is not a report. There is no logical connection between the individual pieces in it. Consequently, it would represent a biased view to the community generally.

—Can the Minister rep- resenting the Minister for Health inform the Senate of the reason the Cabinet apparently has rushed through the pharmacy fees tribunal proposal when it was aware that an application for a fee increase was before the Joint Committee on Pharmaceutical Benefits Pricing Arrangements? Does he agree that this could be seen by pharmacists to be causing unnecessary delay in determining the appropriate fees that should be applicable today for the dispensing of medical prescriptions?

—The Government has been considering for some time the recommendations made by the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts of September last year that the present Joint Committee on Pharmaceutical Benefits Pricing Arrangements be replaced by a fees tribunal. The Minister for Health discussed this subject with representatives of the Pharmacy Guild of Australia at meetings in December 1980 and again in February 1981. It was subsequent to these discussions that the national president of the Pharmacy Guild submitted to the Chairman of the Joint Committee on Pharmaceutical Benefits Pricing Arrangements the Guild's application for an increase in chemists' remuneration for the supply of pharmaceutical benefits. That is the timing of that matter. The Government, however, has taken a policy decision as to the way this should go in future. This is a different mechanism.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. Given the announced intention of the Queensland Government to repeal the notorious Queensland Acts pertaining to Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders, will the Minister state whether it is the intention of the Fraser Government that Aboriginal communities be granted title to reserve areas and to former reserve areas in Queensland? If so, in the absence of effective State legislation to this end, will the Federal Government legislate to give Queensland Aborigines secure title to this land?

—I think it is important to note that the repeal of the Aboriginal affairs legislation of itself would not affect the status of the reserves in Queensland. Queensland Aboriginal reserves are reserves under the Lands Act of that State and it would require action under that legislation to abolish them. That is the first point we need to understand. The Queensland Premier has said already that no action would be taken on the question of abolishing either Act without full consultation with the Aboriginal people. I have already had friendly and, I must say, very useful communications with the new Minister for Aboriginal and Island Affairs in Queensland, Mr Ken Tomkins, and in fact I will be visiting some Aboriginal communities with him in a few weeks. In these circumstances and in view of the consultations which have been promised, it is really quite foolish to talk about Commonwealth intervention at this stage. I was advised as recently as this morning by Mr Tomkins that further consultations are to take place when the Aboriginal council set up in Queensland meets in Brisbane the week after next with the Queensland Government. I think that is the week beginning 6 April. I think we should at least wait to see what those meetings bring forth.

—Is the Attorney-General aware of reported comments by Senator Chipp that the recent decision in the cases challenging certain of the 1980 election results has given the Central Intelligence Agency a green light to invade Australian politics and to attempt to buy off political parties? Can the Minister indicate whether there is any basis for these allegations and whether Senator Chipp has conveyed to the Attorney-General's Department any details of alleged CIA interference? If not, will the Minister instruct his Department to seek this information from Senator Chipp to establish its veracity?

—Mr President, I take a point of order. Senator MacGibbon quotes roughly what I did say; that is, that the decision of the High Court gave the green light to an organisation to invade politics. He then proceeded to ask a question on the basis that I made allegations that the CIA already had invaded Australian politics. He asked the Attorney to answer the question on that basis. With respect, Mr President, if Senator MacGibbon wants to have a go at what I said let him do it honestly, but let him do it within the scope of Standing Orders. That question is clearly outside the scope of Standing Orders.
—No, it is a matter of explanation for you, Senator, in due time. There is no substance to your point of order at this stage.
—Mr President, do I understand that you are ruling against the point of order? Are you saying that Senator MacGibbon's question is totally in order?

—I am not saying that. I cannot vouch for the veracity of any honourable senator's question here. If you claim to have been misrepresented, Senator Chipp, you have at your command the time at which you can refute that misrepresentation.

—Mr President, may I raise another point of order? I know that I have only the Standing Orders of the Senate to challenge your ruling but I just point this out to you: If your present situation and attitude are to obtain, mischief can be done by allowing such a question to be broadcast because then the only redress that I or any other honourable senator would have would be to correct that mischief off air. I suggest that the ruling you have just made, or which you say is not a ruling, is very significant in the administration of this Senate and in relation to the protection of the rights of senators.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I think the opposition to the question is that the question is based on a falsehood. The alleged author of the falsehood has given the assurance that it is a falsehood. As I understand your ruling, someone can ask a question based on a lie and can get an answer. That is the whole point.

—As I have said, Senator Cavanagh, it is not for a presiding officer to have at his fingertips proof of the veracity or otherwise of that which is said by any honourable senator in this chamber, and I abide by that ruling.
—Mr President, I would like to make one further point concerning this point of order or to make another point of order if necessary.
—The point of order has been determined.

—I raise a fresh point of order, Mr President, because I think this is a matter of very great basic importance. I cannot believe that you are saying to us now that an honourable senator can ask a question in this place based on facts which he cannot substantiate and is not prepared to substantiate to the Senate. I think that would be an extremely serious matter. Do I understand, Mr President, that Senator MacGibbon may ask his question with no further obligation to justify to the Senate that what he is saying is in his own estimation absolutely true?
—Of course I cannot answer any hypothetical question, Senator Mason. I call the Attorney-General.

—Mr President, there seems to be considerable controversy about the basis on which this question was asked. I am certainly not familiar with the statement that is alleged to have been made by Senator Chipp in relation to this matter and neither has Senator Chipp referred any such matter to me. I think as Senator Chipp proposes to make some statement in relation to the matter the question should be left until we know just what are the allegations, if any, that Senator Chipp has made.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for National Development and Energy. I refer him to the Government's stated policy of not imposing the crude oil levy or a resource rental tax on production from the Fortescue oil field in Bass Strait. Having regard to the benefits which will flow to the Victorian Government in respect of royalties from that arrangement, is this not yet another example of where a State will collect a tax on a resource that is the property of the Australian nation, particularly an off-shore resource, for which constitutional control resides with the Commonwealth Parliament? What does the Government intend doing about this wellhead value question in relation to Fortescue to guarantee that the nation and not just Victoria benefits from this development?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. It follows the question asked by Senator Davidson about the powers of the River Murray Commission. The Minister, of course, knows that there is an increasing number of requests that the Commission should have more powers. I ask the Minister: Does his reply to Senator Davidson's question indicate that at this time the Australian Government would not support increased and/or enforcement powers over the quality and quantity of water available? Can he indicate at what stage and in which circumstances the Australian Government representative might do so?

—As Senator Bishop knows, this is a Federal-State matter. The degree to which any kind of agreement can be reached depends upon the good will and the unanimity of views of some four partners in this venture. The aim at this moment is to get the maximum co-operation we can within a rewriting of the River Murray Commission agreement and from there to see whether any further steps are necessary. Of course, the aim is to give the River Murray Commission the ability to have an effective overview, to be able to know what is likely to happen not only in regard to the quantity of water but also in regard to the quality of water along the way and to be able to present the evidence of what will happen. One would hope that, through the members of the Commission, the necessary steps would be taken. We believe that a significant step in the journey will be achieved by getting the new agreement signed. If there is any necessity to do more, and if it can be done, we will take those steps. We fully understand the vital nature of getting an adequate volume of water and quality of water down the River Murray to South Australia. That will be a primary target on our part.

—I address my question to the Minister for National Development and Energy. No doubt the Minister has taken note that today South Australian senators have been questioning him on the problem of and the concern about both the quality and the quantity of water in the River Murray system. Is it not a fact that the River Murray Commission mostly does have control over water quantity but has very little control at present over water quality? Is this not a fact because the Commission has virtually no say over the river systems feeding into the main trunk stream of the River Murray? Is it not a fact that, in part, these problems arise because no recommendation can be made by the River Murray Commission unless it has the unanimous support of its members? Will the Government make every effort to rectify this anomaly so that recommendations by the River Murray Commission can be made by a majority decision rather than unanimously as at present and so that the Commission can also have greater power over the quality of water flowing into the system in addition to the water flowing down the main stream?

Of course, it is true that there is a keen interest by all the States and the Commonwealth in the quantity of water. It is equally true that a main preoccupation of the Commonwealth and others at this moment is water quality arising from the prior action of States within their sovereign territories higher up the river system. That is where the nub of the problem lies; they have total sovereignty. Unless we get voluntary co-operation, the journey will be so much the harder. One of the main points we are seeking at this moment is to have the States, in particular New South Wales, let the River Murray Commission know well ahead any significant actions on their part upstream which will alter not only water quantity but also water quality. I stress the words 'significant actions'. That matter will be looked at. Equally, of course--
—You are referring to State Ministers?

—That is right. The River Murray Commission also will keep its eye on environmental impact studies involving industrial plants such as paper mills. It is a question of a federation and State sovereignty. It is true that we need unanimity of support. I suppose it would be good if we could get a majority view. But I do not believe that we would ever get States to agree, when one State is dissenting, that a majority decision should bind them. Nevertheless, hope springs eternal. I say to Senator Young and Senator Bishop that we will strive to get the best result we can.

—My question is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy. Like the questions asked earlier this month, as well as those asked earlier today by Senator Davidson, Senator Bishop and Senator Young, my question concerns South Australia's alarm at the quality and quantity of water in the River Murray. Is the Minister aware that, despite the welcome and useful statements he has made in the Senate about progress in determining new purposes and powers for the River Murray Commission, the people of South Australia continue daily to express enormous concern that the proposed new arrangements for the River Murray Commission will still fall far short of solving the pollution problem? I emphasise that more than half of all water used in South Australia-whether in Adelaide or country areas, and whether for domestic or industrial use-comes from the River Murray. It is quite truly the lifeline of South Australia. —Mr President, I raise a point of order. Senator Teague is putting forward a hypothetical question about future irrigation problems in New South Wales should the irrigation licences be issued. He is asking the Minister to comment on that when the Minister has already told the Senate that each State has its own sovereign rights. The Minister knows that, and I think he ought to be very careful about the way in which he answers the question; otherwise South Australia will get no better quality water because the other States will use their sovereign rights to the detriment of those of us who live in South Australia.

—Questions should be kept brief and should not be hypothetical. There was a suggestion of a hypothetical question in Senator Teague's last few words. I ask the honourable senator to complete his question.

—I am glad that Senator Bishop has spoken in the Senate today along similar lines. —I am aware of the great concern of the people of South Australia about the quantity and quality of the water flowing down the Murray. I am aware that the people of South Australia depend very significantly upon the River Murray. I am equally aware of the salinity question. The Maunsell report, of course, is available. There has been some argument as to the sources of salinity and whether it is from parts of Victoria or from parts of the Darling. That is a controversy that I do not enter into. For example, in the Darling at this moment, due to the drought, there is more salinity coming down because of the dry salt pans. A lot of anti-salinity work is being done at this moment, and that will be expedited. As to the Government's seeking to bring about a moratorium on irrigation, I do not think any Commonwealth government could intervene at the State level on what are solely sovereign powers. What a Commonwealth government can do, and what this Government is doing, is to indicate to the States that any significant extension of irrigation, of riparian rights, would influence the quantity and quality of water. The Government is seeking to bring about a situation in which the River Murray Commission will get to know each episode which could vary these things and, therefore, can adjudicate on what is happening along the river. We will concentrate on this matter. We want to get the best agreement we can. We will look at it in action and, if further action is necessary, we will take it.

—I ask a supplementary question. Will the Minister answer the part of my question concerning consideration of the Commonwealth's financial powers to give incentives to the States to make appropriate decisions with regard to the River Murray system?

—I will look at that, but fundamentally I think it will cut across State sovereignties. The Commonwealth and the States, of course, undertake a national water resources program for which I am responsible; and that program is of assistance in irrigation generally.

DEBATE.TITLE: ACCESS TO AUSTRALIAN FISHING ZONE BY FISHING VESSELS OF TAIWAN

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I seek the indulgence of the Senate to speak very briefly on this matter. It is of particular interest to me basically because Northern Territory coastal waters are involved. I realise, of course, that the area runs over into Queensland and Western Australia, but the majority of the area to be fished is in Northern Territory coastal waters. I have visited a number of the vessels and seen the conditions under which the Taiwanese fishermen carry out their work. I have been involved in Darwin with meetings to discuss the facilities that ought to be made available for the groups of sailors who will stay overnight in Darwin, and I have talked to Northern Territory fishermen about the total situation in the Northern Territory.

I have not read the agreement, but I think it is possible to make a few general comments without having done so. Firstly, I query the return to the Australian people from the exploitation of this Australian resource. I am given to understand that the licence fees charged-the figures may be different when I read the agreement, but my figure is $35 a metre-do not cover the costs of surveillance, of supervision on board the ships or of the inspection of ships' licences. The costs involved are not met by the licence fees which are charged.

It is my contention-as I think it would be of any honourable senators sitting in this place-that licences should cover more than the costs. This plus of which I am speaking could be used to encourage Australian industry. I will be interested to read the agreement, and to see the sorts of royalties involved and the returns to the Australian people.

Two claims have been made publicly in the Northern Territory. I do not know whether they have been made elsewhere. One claim concerns the fact that there is no return to the Australian people from this agreement whereby there is the fishing in our waters by Taiwanese boats. It has been claimed that it actually costs us money to have the ships there. The second claim is that the total return is less than $1m a year. I suppose that one has to assess the costs of surveillance and wonder whether that ought to be covered by licences and so on. I will be very interested to read about this matter in the report. I am very concerned about the fishing methods used by the Taiwanese. It has been alleged to me by professional fishermen and others involved in the industry in the Northern Territory that the Taiwanese adopt a method which would not be accepted by Australian fishermen or the Australian people. The Taiwanese work on the basis of fishing out an area completely and taking everything that is available. These methods are not used by Australian fishermen for the very reason that such a method fishes out all sizes and all types of fish and virtually cleans an area out. I repeat that these methods are not acceptable to Australian fishermen. It has been said to me by people who work in the industry that as a final step the Taiwanese use explosives to get everything in a particular area. I do not have to explain to the Senate the problems associated with this method of cleaning out an area entirely and leaving no resources behind.

These are, I understand, serious allegations. They were made to me very seriously. People are concerned for the resources around our coast. This problem highlights, of course, the need for supervision of foreign fishing boats as they work in Australian waters. But that is not the only need. There is also a need for consultation with industry. I was particularly interested to read the submission made to the Senate Standing Committee on Trade and Commerce by the Australian Fishing Industry Council. I understand that the Committee met last week. As the submission is now a public document I shall read from it. I was interested to read the Council's comments about consultation with the fishing industry. The submission stated:
We are strongly of the opinion that both State and Commonwealth Governments have a responsibility to adequately consult with the industry over which they have administrative control;

The principal responsibility of the Commonwealth is to ensure the 'Australianisation' of the Australian Fishing Zone. By Australianisation of the AFZ we mean that the Australian Government should, in all bilateral and multilateral negotiations regarding the AFZ, adopt an attitude of 'overt favouritism' to the Australian fisherman.
The submission further stated:

It is not uncommon to hear the comment that the land mass of Australia has been turned into a vast quarry for foreign mining companies. Whether you subscribe to that particular ideology or not, we fear that the AFZ could come to be regarded as a vast marine quarry for the more sophisticated foreign fishing fleet if we do not make it abundantly clear to guest nations that they are here as guests and will be politely but firmly asked to withdraw as the Australian industry expands its areas of operations throughout the AFZ.

I support this view strongly and I know that the Northern Territory Professional Fishermen's Association also supports it. I will look at the agreement very closely, when we have a copy, to see whether the Government supports this view also. I know that the licences are issued annually but I wonder about the philosophy behind this. Can we look towards an Australianisation of our industry and a movement away, over the years, from the present Taiwanese group taking into account, of course, the comments I made earlier concerning the methods used by the Taiwanese and the effect this has on our resources. We hear a lot about the multiplier effect. I wonder what it is in this instance. I understand that the bunkering and victualling process presents no return at all to Australia. This process is covered by boats in their main ports or by other ships. I know that we do not have much processing on the north coast but I wonder whether there is some suggestion in the agreement that if we have processing plants erected there will be some requirement on foreign fishing vessels to use them? I wonder whether the small ship facility is required to be used. I understand that this is not the case and that ships return to their home bases. I would want to see some return from that aspect as well. I will be looking to see whether there is in the Agreement any obligation on foreign vessels to use this facility.

I mentioned earlier that I had been involved in some discussions about visiting sailors coming into the Port of Darwin. The suggestion was made that we should have some type of sailors' rest facility, that boats should be encouraged to stay overnight and that sailors should be given some time to come ashore. My information in respect of the multiplier effects is that the sailors have nothing to spend. The workmen on the boat do not get paid until they return to Taiwan. I am told that the only people who have money to spend are the two officers on board-the captain and the radio officer-and that they buy only those things which they cannot bring with them from Taiwan. So we will be looking not only for a return from the fishery resource but also something from the multiplier effects as well.

How can we encourage the Australian fishing industry? Firstly, we must make finance available. This is one of the points made in the submission by the Australian Fishing Industry Council. I notice that Senator Archer, who is interested in this subject, is taking a keen interest in what I am saying. I hope he will make a contribution either today or at a later stage on this matter of the provision of finance because at the present time it is not readily available to the Australian fishing industry. I will not go through all of the details because the information is set out in the submission but I do know that finance is not available from banks such as the Commonwealth Development Bank or from any of those groups which we hope would support this primary industry. I have suggested one alternative method of raising finance, that is, the use of additional money from licences to encourage industry development. This could be done by a form of loans or in some other way. I hope that the Government will be able to find some way to encourage banks to lend money to the fishing industry so that individuals can become established.

I think the regulations imposed on the fishing industry should be checked to see, firstly, whether they are too stringent and, secondly, whether the application of the regulations is consistent from year to year. The Australian Fishing Industry Council stated in its submission:
Fishing is a highly regulated industry. To the extent that our resources are limited and vulnerable to over-exploitation, this principle of regulation is welcomed.

To the extent that we are afflicted with seemingly endless rules, amended rules, revised rules, substituted rules, ad infinitum, over a myriad of issues, such as labelling and packaging of our product for export, we are less than amused. More seriously, the Australian Fishing Industry has been, and is currently being, placed at a severe marketing disadvantage in world markets as a result of the added cost of meeting Government requirements.

In brief let me say that the fishery resource is ours. It belongs to the Australian people. I have put forward a proposition that we should benefit from this resource. I have raised the question of whether we are benefiting and if so, are we benefiting to the full or even sufficiently under the present conditions. I look forward to reading the Agreement to see how much return there is to be to the Australian people-how much Government encouragement there is to the Australian fishing industry. I repeat my concern about the fishing methods that the Taiwanese use. I once again draw attention to the absolute necessity for the Government to supervise this industry. I look forward to seeing in the Agreement what arrangements have been made in this regard. I seek leave to continue my remarks.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Mason has indicated that he would like to speak. I call Senator Mason.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I want to make two points in regard to this matter. The first confirms, or is a parallel to, what Senator Robertson has just said but it relates not so much to the Northern Territory as it does to the North West Shelf. In the first place, I believe it would be unfair and certainly a dog in the manger attitude for Australians to say that we should not allow any of our fishery products to be made available to the people of Asia who need them so badly. At the same time, I think it is going too far along the path of charity if we actually do this to the extent that we disadvantage our own industry and our own people in a fairly serious way, and I understand that this is what is happening. Indeed, that is the view put by the Australian Fishing Industry Council on North West Shelf fishing by the Taiwanese. The Council's contention is that the pattern of fishing by the Taiwanese on the North West Shelf will make it uneconomic for an Australian boat to work that area and will probably make it uneconomic to work the area for many years or possibly for even decades to come, the reason being that the people in Asia who the Taiwanese supply have a predilection for very small fish, wasteful though that would seem to us. Indeed, it is wasteful. They do not want large fish; they want small fish. For that reason we have apparently come to an agreement with the Taiwanese on the size of trawling nets. The mesh limitation is only 50 millimetres on nets used by trawlers working the North West Shelf.

SPEECH.PARA: I also gather from the Australian Fishing Industry Council that the Taiwanese put one net inside another. This virtually halves the net size and the size of the fish caught. To use the old terminology they are catching fish as small as one inch long. I gather that these are snapper and bream, the sort of fish which, if allowed to grow to maturity, would be perfectly satisfactory for the Australian market. Further, the Australian Fishing Industry Council makes a very serious claim that this is one of the major fishing grounds of Australia. We are having to import fish. It was said to me by members of the Council that they would have no doubt that if this fishing ground were allowed to develop so it would be fished by Australian vessels we would not have to import fish. So, we have got ourselves into a ridiculous Gilbertian situation. We are allowing the starving millions of Asia to catch fish an inch long-and the fish are not being allowed to grow any bigger-while at the same time we are forcing ourselves into the situation where we will have to import fish permanently.

The Australian Democrats ask whether we should try to negotiate this situation a little further. I do not believe that our fisheries should be depleted to the extent of supplying merely a matter of taste. It is a fact that the people of Asia will be nourished just as easily on fish a foot long as on fish an inch long, except if the fish are only small a lot more will be required to make up the catch. This is a serious matter. It is serious to our fishing industry which needs all the support it can get. It is suffering now because of a reverse action of the economies of scale. Our fishing industry is not the size that it wants to be. If we bring in new modern boats we will need fishing grounds where fish which suit the Australian taste can be caught.

I raise my second point more briefly. We are on the verge of having our first research ships of marine science built in Australia. The Australian Democrats make the plea on this matter that we have made so many other times: Can these ships be built in Australia? I have no doubt that that question could be answered in one way. Of course, it is possible to build them in Australia. We are asking that a reasonable view be taken of the economics of this matter so that we may have the opportunity of getting our shipbuilding industry back on the ground again instead of witnessing the constant destruction of our industries one after another to the benefit of foreigners. If this cannot be done, and if a tender goes to a foreign builder-in spite of the best wishes I believe of most Australians who would like to see these ships built here-Australians should have some share in the project, either by way of a joint venture or some similiar arrangement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-When this agreement came before the chamber on 20 November 1979 I moved that the Senate take note of it. I take it that this is the same agreement.
—It is a new one.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Interim Report on Parliament and the Scrutiny of Science Policy

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I present the interim report of the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association Study Group on Parliament and the Scrutiny of Science Policy held in Ottawa in November 1980. I seek leave to make a brief statement relating to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had the honour to represent the Commonwealth of Australia Branch of the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association at the meeting of the CPA Study Group on Parliament and the Scrutiny of Science Policy in Ottawa from 23 November to 27 November 1980. This was the second of the study groups initiated by the Executive Committee of the Association and financed by its newly-established working capital fund. The study group comprised delegates from seven branches of the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association-the United Kingdom, Canada, Australia, India, Singapore, Kenya, Trinidad and Tobago-selected and invited by the General Assembly of the Association and representing its seven geographical regions, and a representative from the kindred group of the Congress of the United States. The Chairman was Lord Sherfield, G.C.B., G.C.M.G., former President of the United Kingdom Atomic Energy Authority, Chairman of the Imperial College of Science and Deputy Chairman of the House of Lords Select Committee on Science and Technology. The Rapporteur was Mr D. N. Clay, Chief, Science and Technology Division, Research Branch of the Canadian Library of Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: Because of the small number involved, the participants quickly established a personal rapport. The discussions were a very good exercise in the exchange of information, communication and mutual support. The industrialised countries found that they shared common problems in the domestic and international fields. The less developed countries were rather more concerned with information and advice relevant to specific scientific and technological initiatives that had already been taken. Throughout the discussions there was emphasis on the need for a readily accessible bank of information which would help parliamentarians to understand better how science and technology can be harnessed to serve the nation. The discussions of the study group clearly demonstrated that there is a general awareness among parliamentarians of the massive impact that scientific and technological development will have on the lifestyle on this, the next and future generations of mankind and on national welfare and progress, and can have on international understanding, co-operation and independence. Several members, however, evidenced their concern that the curricula of our educational institutions at university and technical college level is not keeping pace with research and the implementation of new techniques. There was a consensus that the legislature, through the Executive, should give a positive lead in the framing of national educational objectives. Such legislative direction, of course, calls for a well-informed parliament.

This is an interim report. A full report, compiled by the Rapporteur, will be published by the Headquarters Secretariat of the Association and distributed to all Commonwealth parliaments. I received a letter today from Mr Ian Clay explaining that there will be a delay in the presentation of the report because the Rapporteur concerned is dealing in Canada at the moment with a select committee inquiring into alternative energy sources. So, the report will be presented later than we would have liked. I should like to congratulate the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association on its initiative in setting up these forward-looking study groups, the host branch of Canada on its organisation, and the Secretariat on its skill and efficiency. I also wish to acknowledge the support of the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment and particularly its staff; the invaluable assistance of the Departments of Science and Technology, Trade and Resources and the Treasury in providing briefing material; our Mission in Washington which seconded Dr Richard Brock as an adviser and observer; and our Consulate-General in New York and our High Commission in Ottawa for their courtesies and facilities. I think it is also appropriate to mention at this stage Mr John Ferguson and our staff in Canberra for the help they have given me, and Sue Boyd, our Foreign Affairs Parliamentary Liaison Officer, for the help that she was able to provide. Finally, I am grateful for the privilege of representing the Parliament and the Commonwealth Branch at this very useful exercise in Commonwealth co-operation.
