TALK.START.PARA: —I present a statement made by the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Street, in another place today. I seek leave to incorporate the statement in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

It is now five months since I was appointed Minister for Foreign Affairs, not long enough to justify a comprehensive survey of Australia's foreign relations and interests, but long enough-and full enough-to justify my setting out some preliminary impressions concerning the nature of this country's foreign policy and some of the more urgent tasks facing it. The first thing that is brought home very forcibly to a new Minister for Foreign Affairs is the complexity which Australia's external relations have now assumed. In this respect there has been a profound change in recent years. The much tighter integration of the international community, the gradual recognition of interdependence and the emergence of institutions to manage it, the development of Australia itself, changes in our region-all these have moved us rapidly to the stage where Australia is now a significant middle power with a range and depth of relations comparable with any country, other than a handful of great powers.

Today our foreign policy is concerned increasingly not only with the classic issues of security and political relations, but also with trade and aid, with energy and food, with immigration and refugees, and with communications and transport. In its role as a middle power, Australia needs a foreign policy which encompasses not just bilateral relations but the multilateral diplomacy of international organisations and blocs of countries acting together. And, of course, it continues to include the day to day problems of individual people which assume even greater proportions as the personal contacts between nations rapidly increase.

In a general sense, of course, this is well known, but we need to come to terms with what such a wide-ranging or total foreign policy means, what implications it carries in terms of co-ordination, the balancing of differing and sometimes competing interests, the addressing of multiple audiences, and the use of scarce human resources. Increasing complexity also makes it more important than ever to have a clear sense of Australia's national interest, defined in an enlightened and long term way, so that we can determine our priorities sensibly.

I believe that it is essential to understand the needs that have to be served by the foreign policy of a middle power such as Australia. If we are to get things right in what, by general consensus, is going to be a difficult and dangerous decade, the gap between the complexity of our foreign policy, as it really is, and public perception and discussion of that policy must be narrowed.

I intend to give this matter careful consideration, to see what can be done on the Government's side, to stimulate and promote discussion of the issues which face us. I have just referred to Australia as a significant middle power. This has become a familiar term of self-definition in recent years, but I do not think that we give sufficient attention to what such a status implies, what characteristics a middle power has as an actor on the world scene.

The first point to make is that the designation 'middle power' refers to one's overall global position and one's status in terms of the whole range of international issues. It does not define a nation's importance in terms of particular isues or circumstances. The 'weight' of a middle power can be very considerable indeed within its region-as ours is in South East Asia and the South West Pacific. It can be very considerable in a particular forum-as ours is in the Commonwealth. And it can be very considerable in relation to particular resources-again, as ours is in relation to food and energy. In contrast, of course, on a range of other international matters our significance is less. This considerable variability in 'weight', depending on the issue and the circumstance, is one of the key characteristics of a middle power. It is one which demands very considerable judgment and flexibility in assessing situations and Australia's response to them.

Closely allied to this, and again pointing to the need for sure judgment, is the fact that the balance of opportunities and constraints facing a middle power is more complicated and ambiguous than it is for either the very small or the very powerful. A middle power has more opportunities-and therefore more temptations to overreach itself-than a small power; and it faces more constraints-and therefore greater danger that it will be unduly cautious and timid-than a great power. Certainly the problem of striking and maintaining a proper, realistic balance between opportunity and constraint is at the core of middle power diplomacy.

Both these characteristics point to a third feature of middle power foreign policy: That quality of performance is particularly important in determining influence and status. Great powers are, almost by definition, going to be important in any event; while lack of power sets definite limits on the influence of small countries. But the variable positions of middle powers mean that how seriously they are taken and what impact they have on events in which they are involved will depend largely on the quality of human performance-on the skill, knowledge, maturity, determination and imagination of those who formulate and implement their policies.

Obviously this means that it is essential that the conduct of Australia's foreign policy at the professional level be of a high standard. But it means more, much more, than that. It means that in the kind of society Australia is-the values it embodies; the degree of consensus and bi-partisanship that exists within it; the clarity with which its national interests are perceived; the kind of leadership it enjoys; and, if I may use an old-fashioned but indispensible term, the quality of its patriotism-these things have a great bearing on the effectiveness of our foreign policy. In other words, we should not think of the term 'middle power' in fixed terms, as implying a given status which cannot be changed one way or another. The human factor is vital; it can enhance or diminish us very significantly as international actors.

My fourth point is that the range of issues on which we, as a middle power, can and should concentrate substantively is necessarily limited, because our resources are limited. We must be selective and resist both temptation from within and pressure from without to extend ourselves unrealistically. The issues on which we can act in this sense must be determined by our national interest and will usually be in our region or will relate to special political, strategic or economic interests that we have. Having said that, however, it is important to go on to make a distinction between the scope of the substantive policies I have been discussing and the scope of what might be called declaratory policies.

By declaratory policies I am referring to the obligation of a middle power to declare its position on all major issues-issues of war and peace, freedom and oppression, racialism, development and poverty. Australia's interests are now sufficiently wide-ranging and our status is sufficiently recognised for it to be not only legitimate but also proper for us to do just that-proper because ultimately those issues can have a serious impact on us, as indeed history has repeatedly demonstrated in this century, and proper also because, in some circumstances, a middle power can be more effective than a great power, precisely because it does not bring too much power to bear on the situation and does not automatically engage the interest of other great powers. Our intervention in the Zimbabwe conflict was a clear case in point. I believe that this is important in considering the opportunities available to a middle power: In some situations limited power is an asset rather than a liability.

In making the distinction between substantive and declaratory policies, it is important to point out that it is a serious mistake to think of the first as the only ones which are real and important and that the second are merely a matter of posturing. If we have not yet learnt that words, symbols and arguments representing genuinely and strongly held views are important in international affairs, we have learnt very little. The history of this century has demonstrated that they are often crucial.

My next observation is that, for a middle power like Australia which is allied to a super-power, the management of that relationship constitutes a particularly important part of its diplomacy. The ANZUS alliance receives bi-partisan support in this country and it is eminently desirable that it should continue to do so. While the Alliance is reinforced by ties of friendship and cultural similarities, it is based firmly on considerations of national interest. That is not to say, of course, that Australia's national interests and those of the United States always coincide. Indeed, it would assist the management of the alliance relationship if it were appreciated that differences must exist in an alliance between powers of a very different magnitude. Far from being peculiar to the Australian-American relationship, it is entirely normal. It derives from the necessary trade-offs between the desire to maximise the benefits of co-operation and shared interests on the one hand, and the concern to safeguard independence of action on the other. We should neither deny the existence of these differences nor engage in paranoid exaggeration concerning them. We should rather accept them as a part of life and work out our policies accordingly, appreciating as we do that our super-power ally is a free, democratic and pluralistic country. Quite clearly the development of this middle power concept is closely linked to the practical formulation of foreign policy.

I turn now to some of the issues which are currently in the forefront of Australian foreign policy. In doing so I shall not try to be comprehensive but shall focus on those aspects which my pattern of visits to date has highlighted. The first one is Kampuchea. In the last five months I have had the opportunity of discussing this question in four member countries of the Association of South East Asian Nations, as well as in Tokyo, Peking and Washington. That is, I have discussed it in every like-minded country, apart from New Zealand and Singapore, that has a serious interest in the maintenance of peace and stability in South East Asia. Naturally, I will be looking to discuss the issue of Kampuchea with those two countries at the earliest opportunity. During my recent visit to the United States I also had the opportunity to have a very useful discussion on Kampuchea with the United Nations Secretary-General Dr Waldheim. Australia regards the implementation of the United Nations resolution on Kampuchea as essential for the restoration of peace in the region.

I want to stress that on the basic issues involved in Kampuchea, our interests coincide with the countries I have mentioned. There should be no misunderstanding about this, either in Australia or outside it, or about the meaning of our derecognition last month of the so-called Government of Democratic Kampuchea. That act of derecognition was based on two considerations, one moral and one practical. Morally, the regime in question was so repugnant that we felt that continuing recognition was unjustifiable; practically, as long as the question of recognition remained unsettled it would confuse and distract attention from the basic strategic and political questions at issue.

Powerful as these considerations were, the balance of arguments was not clear cut. Against them, the Government had to weigh the opinions and interests of other countries in the region who share our basic interests. Some of them are much closer to the sharp end than we are and have had to bear a much greater burden as the result of what has happened to Kampuchea. This affected the timing of our act of derecognition. The Government makes no apology for this but I want to make it clear beyond any doubt and ambiguity that our opposition to Vietnam's invasion of Kampuchea remains implacable. We reject outright that that invasion proceeded on the basis of a concern for the welfare of the Khmer people. We reject outright the claim that the Heng Samrin regime, which the invasion installed, is the legitimate representative of the Khmer people. We deplore and oppose the continued Vietnamese occupation of Kampuchea because it denies the independence of the Khmer people, because it affects the security of Thailand and other Asian countries, because it holds the threat of Vietnamese hegemony in the region and because it imports a Soviet strategic presence into the region. In this last respect, I draw attention not only to the significant strategic presence which the Soviet Union has now achieved in Indo-China, but also to the fact that Vietnam launched its invasion of Kampuchea only after it had signed a so-called treaty of friendship and co-operation with the Soviet Union. It was this which gave it the security guarantee against China which was a condition for its attack.

We deeply regret Vietnam's refusal to accommodate the legitimate interests and concerns of its neighbours and to play a more constructive and co-operative role in the region. In the end Vietnam itself will be the greatest loser as a result of its actions, in terms of isolation internationally and from its neighbours, and of domestic economic difficulties and social strains, which have been identified as causes for serious concern by the Vietnamese authorities themselves. Australia will continue to support actively the interests of the ASEAN countries in restoring stability to the region and the implementation of the United Nations Resolution on Kampuchea. With respect to the region, we want nothing but the restoration of peace and stability, the conditions which will allow its prosperity to grow-but we are serious in wanting that. We will watch carefully the efforts to create a new political grouping of Khmers-what is sometines referred to as a 'third force'-and will naturally review our position if the situation changes significantly.

In January I visited two great Asian powers situated further to the north-Japan and China. I was pleased to have confirmed that with both of these ancient and formidable nations Australia has been able to establish a sound relationship, based in both cases on mutual economic advantage, goodwill, and a degree of common perception of the international scene. With Japan, of course, we have more in common-in terms of similar democratic and free enterprise institutions, of our relations with the United States, and the way we view events on the mainland of Asia. China is a participant in those events, and a most important one. Our interests and China's are not always the same, but as I said we have many perceptions in common-concern about Soviet policies and intentions, for example, and a wish to see stability in East Asia.

Honourable members will be aware of recent reports of the results of the re-examination of economic policies and priorities that has been going on in China and the restraints which have resulted from this. As far as Australia's own commercial interests in China are concerned, the policy of restraint could well lead to a reduction in demand for some commodities supplied from Australia, but these reductions seem likely to be limited, and Chinese interest in economic and technological co-operation with Australia remains high.

It is not an easy task for China's leaders to maintain a steady policy course, given the scale of the problems they face and the awakened aspirations of their people for a better and more predictable life. However, after the convulsions and distortions of the Cultural Revolution, more pragmatic leaders, who seek to meet these aspirations, have emerged. China's present leaders now look back with bitterness at the years of the Cultural Revolution and its wasted efforts. Vice-Chairman Deng Xiaoping told me in January that it would take longer to undo the harmful effects of the Cultural Revolution than it had to cause them. Despite this, Chinese leaders were resolute in saying that they were facing up to the task of rehabilitation, were conscious of the demands of their people, and that broad policy lines would not change. I found these statements welcome. I believe that it is in our broad political and strategic interest, as well as in our bilateral commercial interest, that China maintain its outward-looking orientation and 'Window to the West'. When I refer to strategic interests, I have in mind the global balance, the Asia-Pacific area, and North Asia in particular, where four great powers-China, Japan, the Soviet Union and the United States-are all involved, and where China's favourable disposition is of considerable importance.

I turn now to the question of our relationship with the United States under the new Administration. Recently, as honourable members will know, I have had the opportunity of speaking to several of the key foreign policy and national security members of the Administration, including Vice-President Bush, Secretaries Haig and Weinberger and Ambassador Kirkpatrick. The first point I should make is that I gained a clear impression from my private discussions that what these important members of the Administration have been saying in public is not merely rhetoric for its own sake. They mean what they say, they believe that important changes are required in American foreign policy, and they will not easily be deflected from their course. The Administration is proceeding in a very deliberate way and I believe that the end result of the series of comprehensive policy reviews now in train will be a greater degree of predictability in the content and conduct of American foreign policy. This is a development which Australia, for its part, will welcome.

Secondly, I was struck by the extent to which the philosophical perspectives and the analysis of the international situation of the Reagan Administration and of the Australian Government-as set out in a series of statements over the last five years-coincide. I refer particularly to a shared concern about the grave implications of the remorseless military build-up by the Soviet Union, about the need to maintain a military balance as a condition for stability and effective negotiations, about the need to improve consultation and co-ordination within the Western Alliance, about the need for purposeful American leadership, and about the need to pay close attention to crisis situations outside the West itself.

Thirdly, I was left with the very firm impression that the attitude of the new Administration to military power is not-I repeat not-that there should be early recourse to it in order to settle disputes. On the contrary, it is that the possession of adequate power is desirable precisely because it reduces the chances of armed conflict. It is believed, and the Australian Government shares this belief, that it is uncertainty, vacillation, disunity and weakness which increases the prospect of war by inviting expansionist, aggressive behaviour by States seeking to change the balance of power to their own advantage. Preparedness and evident resolution diminish the prospect of war. I stress this point because, either inadvertently or deliberately, it is often misrepresented. There are always some who, while they find it possible to remain silent in the face of huge military efforts on the part of the Soviet Union, raise the cry of war-mongering whenever the West shows any sign of matching that effort.

Fourthly, the new Administration believes that the various elements of foreign policy-economic matters, human rights, strategic and political questions-cannot be treated as separate and distinct but that they must all be seen as components of the whole. This may be the most valid meaning of that much-used concept 'linkage'. Currently, this is particularly relevant to the way in which the issues at stake in Central America are viewed. For our part, the Australian Government believes that human rights issues are of the greatest importance. But we also believe it wrong to assume that economic reform issues and human rights can be divorced from questions of security and strategy. That distinction does not serve the cause of strengthening these rights. There are precious few human rights in the Soviet Union and Cuba, or in the regimes they support and install.

Lastly, the fact that there is broad agreement between the Australian Government and the Reagan Administration on the analysis and evaluation of international affairs should not be taken as implying that there will be automatic or across-the-board agreement between us. The very nature of international politics means we shall have our differences. Our perspectives as a regional power, as a developed country with almost exclusively Third World neighbours, and as a member of a multi-racial Commonwealth will necessarily differ from those of a global super-power on occasions. As an ally of the United States we will continue to pursue as helpful and co-operative a role as possible in the responses of the United States and the West generally to particular situations as they emerge. At the same time, however, Australia will seek to make its contribution on the basis of an independent national judgment, as is currently the case in the Indian Ocean. Equally important, Australian assistance can only be on the basis of complete consistency with Australia's national interests and the maintenance of our national sovereignty. I believe that these realities are well understood and accepted in Washington.

The fourth and last issue-or complex of issues-that I want to touch on is that of North-South relations. This is an area where Australia, as a middle power and an active and important trading nation, can play a role. Among developed countries Australia has distinctive interests. They derive from our geographical position and the regional concerns flowing from it, as well as some features of our own economy. But there are also vital global interests to be served in efforts to resolve North-South issues. This Government is deeply committed to the view that the peace and stability of the world between now and the end of this century will depend to a very considerable extent on progress towards easing the tensions between developed and developing countries. Efforts must be made to assist the developing world to solve its problems. Only those with an interest in instability and conflict will benefit if progress is not made.

Promoting the evolution of a better and more equitable international economic order also holds out the prospect of benefits for both North and South. Assisting the South to realise its full potential will provide significant economic opportunities for the North. It has to be recognised that, in some important respects, this year is not propitious for North-South dialogue. There are increasing pressures on scarce budget resources and trends towards restriction of trading opportunities which make progress more difficult. The combination of serious economic difficulties in developing countries, including continuing inflation and reduced growth rates, with increased East-West tension centred on Afghanistan, Poland and El Salvador, has distracted attention from North-South issues and created an unfavourable climate. Impatience and cynicism feed off each other.

The Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting which is to be held in Melbourne in September will provide a unique opportunity this year for leaders from both North and South to transform the dialogue over North-South issues into practical measures. At the last Commonwealth Meeting of Heads of Government in Lusaka, two years ago, those present succeeded in resolving the problem of Zimbabwe. Until then it had defeated all efforts at solution. In the same way I hope that at Melbourne the leaders of the Commonwealth will succeed in making that meeting a significant landmark with respect to North-South issues. We should certainly aim for such a result. We would want to see such progress translated into effective and sustainable practical programs which would help to mobilise national and international efforts in the development task. Returning to the point which I stressed earlier, it may be that a determined initiative by a number of middle powers has a better chance of getting things moving in present circumstances. Certainly Australia, as host, will try to give a resolute lead in that direction.

Mr Speaker, in concluding what has been in the nature of an interim report to Parliament, I would like to say that in the visits I have so far paid to heads of government and foreign ministers I have been very struck by the regard and respect paid to Australia. I think the point is worth making because, while we have in the past occasionally exaggerated our importance in the world, more often we are inclined to indulge our Australian gift for scepticism and deflation by insisting on our comparative insignificance. This is not only self-damaging; it is plainly wrong. We are, as I have been at pains to emphasise, a significant middle power. There is an important role for us to play in our region, in the Western alliance, in the Commonwealth, in the United Nations and in the North-South dialogue. We must have the will to respond to the challenge, and the determination to make the most of our opportunities.

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

I have not had the opportunity to peruse the statement as fully as I would like but I wish to make one or two comments about it. Most of the statement is, as it were, a lecture to the members of this Parliament about the foreign policy considerations which any country might be confronted with. I take it that it stems from the quilled pen of Professor Owen Harries. It is couched in very familiar terms for those of us who have read earlier works by that gentleman. It is not until the latter stages of the statement that the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) seeks in any way to deal with the real foreign policy issues with which this country is confronted. One of the first things that the Government tries to do in every statement of this kind at this stage of the year is provide some free advertising for the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting to be held in Melbourne later this year, which the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) will no doubt be seeking to use as a sounding board in his efforts to be recognised as an international statesman. So, there is a lengthy paragraph about that meeting in the statement.

There are one or two things which the statement stresses as being important in respect of which, as usual, the Government's rhetoric is very different from the Government's performance. I refer first of all to the question of the so-called North-South dialogue and the importance of the provision of foreign aid. I draw the Senate's attention to the fact that Australian aid as a percentage of gross national product has now fallen to 0.4 per cent. A number of statements have also been made-not in this document-which look threatening to Australia's future in respect of provision of multinational aid of one kind or another. The second point I make is that the Government stresses, as always, the importance of nuclear safeguards. That is a matter in which again the performance of the Government does not match its rhetoric.

There has been a steady decline in the requirements of nuclear safeguards under the Fraser Government. There has been a desperation to sell Australia's uranium resources to any potential buyer and a decline in the requirements made on those purchases in respect of the safeguards which purchasing countries are required to observe. Of course, the statement is light on the matter of Australian research and on the use of nuclear power in a peaceful way in terms of the provision of energy and the sort of technology and research that might go into that area in Australia. It is also totally silent on the matter of waste disposal. To that extent the statement is inadequate because these are matters which have been of public concern in Australia. They are matters which a statement of this kind ought to deal with.

As usual the statement is heavy on blustering rhetoric about the Soviet Union. We have become used to that. Of course, there is no comment in the statement about the question of trade with the Soviet Union which is again I think a matter of legitimate concern to the Australian people. One wonders about the validity of the bluster about the evils of the Soviet Union which springs from the mouths of Ministers and Prime Ministers who trade to their own personal advantage with the Soviet Union on almost a month by month basis. That is again an extraordinary omission from the statement. There appears to be no willingness to deal with that matter of our trading relationships with the Soviet Union. TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I take advantage of the Senate Standing Orders to speak to the first reading of a money Bill. I wish to deal with a situation that exists amongst the employees of the Australian National Railways Commission which I believe deserves some attention from the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt). I hope that by drawing the attention of this House to the situation we will reach some reasonable solution to the problem. The Tasmanian Government Railways, as it was, was taken over by the Australian National Railways Commission and is now operating very efficiently. One result of the development of that efficiency has been a considerable drop in railways staff, and it is the manner in which that staff decrease is being achieved that I wish to raise. I quote the case of a Mr Barwick, and I believe that this example is typical of many, who was employed by the Tasmanian Government Railways, and later the Australian National Railways, for some 19 years and had an impeccable employment record. He was superannuated from the railways under rule 307 of the Australian National Railways Commission rules, which provides:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commission may in addition to its powers under Rule 177-
That is, the rule which enables people to be laid off-
retire an employee who is by reason of injury or illness unable to perform his regular duties on the ground of invalidity after consideration of a Medical Officer's report.

When inquiries were made about Mr Barwick's retrenchment, the reason given was that a report from the Commonwealth Medical Officer had declared Mr Barwick ineligible for work. On investigation, we discovered that the Commonwealth Medical Officer in his area was not only the Commonwealth Medical Officer but also, as it happened, Mr Barwick's private medical practitioner. I shall quote from a letter from his private medical practitioner, to whom he had been referred as Commonwealth Medical Officer, who was asked by the Secretary of the Australian Railways Union in Tasmania why this man had been invalided out of the service. The letter states:
Dear Sir,
Thank you for your note re Colin Barwick.
This man presented to me both as a patient of the practice and in my capacity as a Commonwealth Medical Officer. He informed me that he had been put off from the railways because of his back.

He has never presented to me with back trouble and although he says that he gets some back pain from time to time it has not been a great problem for him. I was concerned that Mr Barwick had been put off from the railways when he had not been having any problems with his back requiring sick leave. Admittedly he was not doing the job, i.e. Fettler, for which he was in fact listed with the ANR, but this was a railways decision as I understand it rather than his. He was in fact doing the job of Plant Operator.
I believe that the ANR simply wanted to reduce staff and found this a convenient way of doing it.

That latter sentence not only was the view of the doctor but also increasingly has been the view of the union looking after the interests of men employed by the Australian National Railways Commission in Tasmania. Later I wrote to the Minister for Transport concerning the decision to dismiss Mr Barwick on medical grounds. I was informed that the decision was made by a senior medical officer in Hobart, whom I understand has never examined Mr Barwick.

This raises a problem for Mr Barwick, and an even greater problem for other employees of the ANRC who are in this situation. After 19 years of service Mr Barwick has superannuation and some payments will be made to him because of the contributions he has made over the years. However there are others in the service-I am told about 100-who do not have superannuation who have been retrenched below the age pension eligibility age, and whose severance conditions are only one week's pay for each year of service. Mr Barwick, like many others in this situation, although declared unfit for work in the ANRC, does not qualify for an invalid pension because the conditions for being superannuated from the railways on medical grounds are much less stringent than the conditions for acquiring an invalid pension, which most people in this chamber know involve 85 per cent disability and some certainty that that disability is permanent.

The question that arises in the minds of railwaymen in Tasmania, and I dare say in other branches of the ANRC, the question that certainly was raised by Dr Rayner in his report on Mr Barwick, and certainly the question in my mind, is whether these medical grounds are being used as a means to retrench workers employed in what was previously the Tasmanian Government Railways, to hurry up the reduction in staff. When the railways were taken over by the ANRC there was a guarantee that retrenchment would occur only as a result of natural wastage and that people would not be put off because they became supernumerary. The whole issue is complicated by the fact that under the ANRC rules there is no appeal against such a decision. In other words, a man can be superannuated on medical grounds and there is no one to whom he can appeal. Previously under the Tasmanian Government Railways there was an avenue for appeal.

I believe it is a very strange situation that a doctor's report can be used to declare a man unfit when the doctor himself does not believe that that is so and is willing to state publicly and in a report that that is the situation. It is a harsh provision which deprives a man of his job but leaves him without financial support through the social security system, which declares him invalid under the rules of the railway legislation yet does not provide him with an invalid pension after 19 years work with those railways. I raise this matter now to take advantage of the first reading of a money Bill rather than doing it in the wee small hours of the morning in the adjournment debate. I request the Minister for Transport, who is in another place, to look at this problem to see whether we can have some semblance of justice. If the invalidity provisions of the ANRC rules can be used to hurry up retrenchments in that area, then great injustice will be done. Justice certainly will not be seen to be done, and we will have considerable dissatisfaction in the development of what up until now has been a very efficient railway system.

TALK.START.PARA: —The story began about 12 days ago when Victor Manuel Montoya, in company with members of the Building Workers Industrial Union, approached me seeking assistance to remain in Australia. When he mentioned El Salvador I was naturally receptive. I have before me two documents that speak more eloquest than I can on events there. SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The documents read as follows-
Article in 'London Guardian'
The Infant 'Criminals' of El Salvador
By Christopher Dickey

LA BERMUDA, El Salvador-when the shooting dies down, the silence tells you this is a war zone. Only 20 miles away, San Salvador is a thriving city. San Martin, a market town on the way here, is bustling with traffic and people. But then, on the road to Suchitoto, the traffic disappears, as do the people.
''This,'' says the driver of a Green Cross ambulance 'is what you call guerrilla country''.

A lorry load of government troops passes by, their rifles bristle in every direction. They are young men, some of them very young, and many are obviously terrified. Their eyes are wide and staring at embankments and hillsides where any moment a grenade could be launched, a machine gun open fire.

There is a body lying in a drainage ditch. A small dog is pulling furiously at an arm. The sun is hot and the smell of decay is nauseating. A few miles further along the road, the army has retaken Suchitoto, or at least its buildings. Almost all of its people have fled and only soldiers and their paramilitary friends wander through its streets.

Nearby the parched hills around the Guazapa volcano are laced with bunkers and tunnels. This is the height of the dry season-the fields are bare and there is little cover for the insurgents above ground. But the hills still belong to the leftist guerrillas.

The ambulance giving me a ride turns onto a dirt road before reaching Suchitoto, driving slowly, one of its young attendants waving a white flag. All within are aware of the possibility that mines have been laid in the area.

There are small houses, peasant homes amid the burned-out cornfields. But there are no peasants and the houses, little more than one-room shacks, are now charred shells. Only the rattle of the old ambulance breaks the silence.

The driver stops amid a throng of women and babies in front of what was once a grand old hacienda. Now hammocks are slung from its rough-hewn beams. Everywhere there are children. Many are naked. Many have distended bellies from malnutrition, some babies have eyes sealed shut with infections, others are covered with skin lesions from chickenpox. Two suspected cases of smallpox have been discovered.
Of the 1,600 people in the Green Cross camp at La Bermuda, 80 per cent are children under 10 years old. The rest are women and a handful of desolate old men.

''We came here because we were afraid of death', said one young women simply. Her name is Anna and at 28 she is the mother of five children. She comes from San Rafael, a small settlement just a few miles away. She said she felt compelled to come here two months ago.
''The authorities came,'' Anna said. ''There was a stray shot somewhere in the area. They burned my house. They burned it with everything.
''My husband is in San Salvador. He is a construction worker. But I don't know what he is doing. I don't know what has happened to him. We have not seen each other. I was alone''.

No, Anna said, she never had anything to do with the guerrillas or with the ''popular organisations''. Many people in her village did, however, so all were suspect in the government's eyes. ''The crime is to be from the village,'' she said. ''Whether you put yourself into politics or not, the crime is to be from San Rafael. Now it is an abandoned zone.''
''They burn for suspicion,'' Anna said, ''or because they find you alone. Because I am alone they think my husband must with the ''boys''-the guerrillas. They even burned the food.'

Standing nearby, listening, is a women of 43-she looks older-who is tending her own small children and grandchildren. Lucia's house was still standing when she left it three months age. Her husband was killed last summer.
''They took him out of the house at three in the morning,' said Lucia. She said she did not know who 'they' were. She described finding her husband's body, mutilated, the next day.

''There was no reason for it,'' said Lucia. After the killing 'there were days when we ate and many days when we did not. No one helped us at all. Finally, we could not stay in the house any longer in such times as these. We came here.'

The president of the Green Cross, Francisco Zamora, takes a visitor through the camp, past cooking fires and an open latrine, to the clinic where volunteers in their teens attempt to treat the diseases that are rampant. The more serious cases will have to be taken to the capital. There are no doctors here.

In this fiercely divided country, the Green Gross volunteers insist on neutrality, dissociating themselves even from the Roman Catholic Church. Many of the volunteers are barely more than children, 14 or 15 years old. But that is old enough to be a soldier in this country.
Article in 'Backgrounder'
EL SALVADOR

El Salvador has gone beyond being a Central American backwater with a serious human rights problem. External communist backing for the left-wing revolt there has made the country an issue in East/West relations.

Australia considers that the United States is entirely right to cut off that source of disturbance and revolution in an area of traditional United States influence. It also believes that this action must be accompanied by support for economic and social reform, and this view is shared by the United States.

As foreseen in the last 'Backgrounder' article on El Salvador (issue No. 269 of 4 February) that formerly little-known part of Central America has now emerged to unexpected prominence as an issue in East/West relations.

Until recently, Australia's concern with El Salvador was almost exclusively with long-standing, serious violations of human rights there. In the past Australia has several times expressed concern about human rights violations in El Salvador at the United Nations General Assembly and in the United Nations Commission on Human Rights in Geneva. Our concern has now broadened to encompass El Salvador's new international importance as a source of conflict close to the United States.

The United States has shown that the revolt in El Salvador has the backing of the Soviet Union and other communist states, notably Cuba, and the Reagan Administration has declared its determination to counter this Eastern bloc foray into the American hemisphere. Following the capture in November 1980 and January 1981 of several caches of documents held by Salvadoran left-wing guerillas, the United States has been able to provide extensive evidence, which Australian and other assessments find convincing, of a well organised campaign to overthrow the Duarte Government, using externally supplied equipment and weapons. Coordinated by Cuba, the inflow of arms through Nicaragua to guerilla groups inside El Salvador was carefully planned and executed over a period of months, and involved mostly Western-manufactured arms in an effort to cover up the communist source of supply.

Under President Carter, the United States limited its military support for the Government of El Salvador between 1977 and 1979. Military aid was stopped entirely, following the murder of a number of American nuns and missionaries in late 1979, and resumed only in January 1981 when the Carter Administration decided to respond to external communist involvement. This resumption of military aid included the first provision of lethal items since 1977. Once it had fully assessed the situation, the incoming Reagan Administration announced-in early March-its intention to further increase military assistance by twenty million dollars, and to provide an additional twenty United States military training personnel, increasing the number of such advisers to 54. The United States has emphasised that these advisers are not to take part in patrols or combat missions.

Australia recognises the United States' historic interest in Latin America, and believes that the American response to Cuban-supported insurrection in the area is justified. In the words of Prime Minister Fraser, speaking in Parliament on 5 March, 'We consider that the United States is entirely right in seeking to cut off that source of disturbance, that source of revolution' in Latin America.

At the same time, many people have been rightly concerned that military factors should not overshadow the continuing and very basic need for social and economic reform in El Salvador. The Foreign Minister, Mr Street, discussed this with the United States Vice-President, Mr Bush, during his recent visit to Washington, and found that the United States shares this Australian view-that United States military support will be accompanied by support for economic and social reform as two mutually supporting parts of the effort to bring a peaceful and lasting solution to the problems in El Salvador.

TALK.START.PARA: —The central theme of my speech is what should happen to a person who is in Australia on a tourist visa when a disruption occurs in his country. Leaving that aside, last week senior immigration officials, at the instigation of the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Macphee), gave members of the Opposition a full briefing on the Numerical Multifactor Assessment System and certain ideas were expressed on how it could be improved. Anyone who has read the ethnic Press knows that that is a very difficult job and that there are always ideas for revision. Sometimes it is a case of robbing Peter to pay Paul. The point I wish to make is that there is a rising awareness of the need for a more equitable intake of people in dire straits in Latin America, whether we designated them as refugees seeking asylum, as family reunions or as persons with job skills.

SPEECH.PARA: I realise that we cannot achieve complete parity. I have raised this matter at various times before Estimates committees. I also know that our international obligations are such that the United Nations High Commission for Refugees, for geographical reasons, has argued that Australia should have a larger intake of refugees from South East Asia than from the Latin American continent. In fact, I think one of the Brazilian representatives on the United Nations High Commission for Refugees has argued that most Latin American people who are subject to political duress would prefer to go to Mexico or to North America. That argument, to a point, is reasonable. It is fair to say that a number of the Chilean people to whom both the Labor Government and the present Government have given political refuge have permanent residence status but hope one day when democracy beams out again in Latin America, particularly Chile, to go back and take an active part in the reconstruction of their country.

That is not unusual. Many people who fled to England from Hitler between 1936 and 1939 went back to their countries and played a notable role in their reconstruction, particularly Germany. As Senator McIntosh would know, many socialists returned to their countries after the war and helped to rebuild them. We are not arguing about whether a person who is brought to Australia as a political refugee should become an Australian citizen in the long term. I am saying that if we are consistent we should slot in, as it were, people who are, in the main, victims of the military dictatorships in Latin and Central America. One of the documents I have incorporated in Hansard is an article from the London Guardian. It is similar to many articles which have appeared in the London Guardian and the Washington Post. The central theme of it is the plight of the innocent bystanders who are caught in the crossfire between various roving guerrilla bands.

I shall take a little further the case of the gentleman whom I have mentioned. In my letter to the Regional Director-I know that the Minister will read it as I have had it incorporated in Hansard-I stated:
While I admit he is not a full trade union functionary, I intend amplifying the case largely on the theme of relativity as regards people we give sanctuary to on an ideological basis.

I said that for the following reason: Last Thursday night when we received an in-depth briefing from senior officers of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, I asked how we would balance from 1 July the categories of people in immigration queues in various countries in the world. They said: 'The position is that the United Nations High Commission for Refugees and the Austrian Government say that we should take a considerable quota of people who have crossed from some eastern European countries to Vienna'. I do not think it is hard to assess such people. They would be people who are under totalitarian governments of the Left, and I use that word in a broad sense. I would not object to our taking them, but I could give the Senate case histories if I am forced to do so-I have raised this matter before Estimates committees in the past-of engineers in nationalised industries in Romania who obtained jobs with the Comalco company in Australia and who reckoned after 12 months that Comalco was as bad as the eastern European nationalised industries. They are people whom nobody can please. Frankly, some of these immigrants would not fit in anywhere, but because they are coming from eastern Europe we take them. We are more solicitous with them than we are with people such as the El Salvadoran to whom I have referred. To fortify my argument, I shall quote from the Ethnic Press Digest of 18 March 1981 a reference to an article in La Fiamma, which by no stretch of the imagination would be regarded as a left wing ethnic publication. La Fiamma, commenting on the dubious status of the bikini clad Soviet Union girl, stated:
What stinks-
That is the newspaper's word, not mine-
is the tendency to regard as victims all those who live in countries behind the iron curtain and who one day decide to migrate.

I will qualify that. I know that the Minister has asked the Committee on the Determination of Refugee Status to take another look at this case to see how dinkum the girl was. I know that in another case a Soviet Union ship's officer has been given a holding line. The Department has not given him asylum, but has given him another three months in which to re-think his position. Let me say definitely that I have never been backward in criticising the excesses of Stalinism. Of course, I always equate them with the excesses of fascism, whether they be exercised by Franco a decade or more ago or by some of the neo-fascists that are found in many of the Latin American countries.

It is against that background that I refer to the El Salvadoran, Victor Manuel Montoya. I had a Peruvian girl assisting me in interviewing him. I interviewed him a second time. I would say that he would be in his thirties. On the information I received, he has been only a rank and file trade unionist. I make this point because the people who suffer the full brunt of dictatorships and the secret police are student activists and trade union functionaries. When I use the term 'functionary' I mean largely what we would call a State secretary or an organiser. This chap is not one of those people. I know that he has been interviewed by an officer from the Department of Foreign Affairs. I think he has been interviewed in Canberra or that verbal submissions have been made. My information is that at this point the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs feels that he does not have a strong case and that he should leave Australia. I can appreciate the existence of some doubt. When a person is not in the mainstream of agitation against his government or a dictatorship one can always say that he is just one of many, that his living standards might be lower but he is not subject to what is called political duress. I think that is the definition that is generally applied when people seek political asylum.

I know that there is a no-man's land between what the Foreign Affairs Department suggests about political asylum and how the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs accepts that suggestion. In saying that I am adopting a bipartisan attitude. When a former colleague of mine, Senator Willesee, was the Minister for Foreign Affairs, there was a tripartite watching team in Vietnam investigating breaches of ceasefire agreements. One member of that team was Polish, and he defected. The officials cut corners in that case. He went to our Embassy in Saigon and gained a speedy passage to Australia. I do not cavil at that action.

Let me return to my central theme. We are much more receptive to the pleas of a person who says that he is a victim of a government of repression which represents the Left than a person who says he is the victim of a similar government which favours the Right. When I first became a member of the Senate, I used to reply to the Government that it was pretty poor consolation to try to distinguish between the treatment of a person being interrogated by the KGB in Moscow and another being questioned by Franco's secret police as each group would probably use all sorts of instruments to get confessions. In the light of what was said at Question Time today-and our approach must be a balanced one-I believe that the plight of our El Salvadoran colleague ought to be considered.

There is another point that deserves consideration. The argument can be applied right across the board that a country that is too tolerant in these matters will get people flooding in. I do not intend to argue about how far this Government went with the boat people. We are not likely to get a flotilla containing people fleeing from El Salvador. A consideration of the hard statistics with respect of immigration intakes and the cases which go before the Determination of Refugee Status Committee reveals that they are much more loaded with South East Asian people and possibly east Europeans than with people from Latin America. I make the plea to the Minister that the submission that I have made on behalf of the El Salvadoran member be favourably considered.

I always believe in covering my flanks. It could be argued that some activities, which may have to do with the work of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation, the narcotics authorities or a similar area, have not been probed by me. If the Minister lets me know tomorrow of any such matter, I will know that I have been given a bum steer. In my attitude to this El Salvadoran member, I have not gilded the lily and said that he is a top trade union representative. As a matter of fact, I have endeavoured to communicate with the Latin American trade union confederations, equivalent to our own organisations. In some other countries, I have been able to do this; in respect of El Salvador, I have not. I simply refer to the documentation that I have presented. In that respect, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard an extract from a document produced by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs entitled 'From the Ethnic Press'. At page 2 of that document, there is recorded an extract from La Fiamma on what it regards, as I do, as an undue solicitude towards some eastern European migrants.
Leave granted.
The article read as follows-

La Fiamma (9 March), commenting on the ''dubious status'' of Lilian Gasinskaya, says: ''What stinks is the tendency to regard as victims all those who live in countries behind the Iron Curtain and who one day decide to migrate.'' (page 26)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I hope that the Minister will be able to consider this matter favourably. Let me re-emphasise one point. I am aware, as is every honourable senator, that an amnesty was introduced for people illegally resident in Australia as distinct from political refugees. We said at the time that short cuts should not be adopted to enable people who were on tourist visas to convert to permanent resident status. I stand by that statement. When I first raised this El Salvadoran case, I had to tell a group of Colombians and Ecuadorians at the same time that, frankly, they had cheated by overstaying their tourist visas in Australia. I told them that I would not take their cases further. I put that aspect on the record so that the Minister will know that I am being consistent and objective.

SPEECH.PARA: I raise another matter. I hope, with my Deputy Leader, the Honourable Lionel Bowen, to meet within the next few days the new Argentinian Ambassador to Australia. I know that Senator Chipp and Senator Evans have raised several cases similar to those on which I have made representations. Some people would know about the case of Miss Montard. I give credit to the Australian Government and in particular the then Minister for Foreign Affairs, Andrew Peacock, and to Ian Macphee. Australia was prepared to take this girl as a political refugee through our Embassy in the Argentine. The girl was let out for 48 hours to pack her bags to come to Australia and she was put in the Cordoba penitentiary by the authorities in the Argentine. We are to see the new ambassador. Our hope is that, if Argentina wants its image to improve, it will release this girl so that she can come to Australia. Senator Coleman, with her involvement in Amnesty International, probably has heard of the case. The Swiss Government as well as the Australian Government, has interceded. I know that at times we feel good when raising the cases of such people, and our adrenalin even rises, but to be practical we must ask how many of these people we can bring to Australia to get away from such a totalitarian atmosphere. Many of the relatives of these people are working here and are taxpayers and members of trade unions. I repeat that if immigration statistics showed a more equal quota from the various continents of the world our immigration policy would be seen in the eyes of many Latin American groups to be a lot fairer and they would feel that they were not at the end of the queue.

I wish to raise some other matters. The first concerns the Attorney-General, Senator Durack, and relates to the annual report of the Security Appeals Tribunal for the period to 30 June 1980. The civil liberties of many people are concerned. Questions have been asked about a suitable appeals tribunal for people who feel that an ASIO evaluation has been to their detriment. The Security Appeals Tribunal report mentions Dr Deschamp who is the Dean of Trinity College at the University of Melbourne and Chairman of the Migrant Resource Centre. He was the member of the Tribunal experienced in migrant affairs. When the Minister first sent me a copy of the report, I ascertained that an appointment had not yet been made to that position. We have had lengthy debates on ASIO. This is one of the areas where somebody can be adversely affected. I would like to know as soon as possible why there has been a delay and when an appointment will be made.

The final matter I raise is again directed at Senator Durack. It is a matter on which I took the trouble, rightly, to defend the motives of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I refer to the ineptitude of senior officers of the Australian Soccer Federation. I have in my sights particularly Sir Arthur George. If a person wants to represent Australia in any sport to my mind he has to meet our rules and citizenship requirements. Senator Peter Baume on one occasion asked what perhaps I would call a loaded question of Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle. He asked whether the Australian Soccer Federation had had lengthy discussions with the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. The answer was yes. If a player came to Australia on a signed contract and pyramided that contract to extend his stay for six years he could probably be fairly close to getting permanent residence. Let us consider the problem with the Australian Soccer Federation. It is not a matter of being nitpicking. The Australian Soccer Federation makes Australia look silly. One tour included Jimmy Rooney, an Irishman, and two Englishmen. Those players were travelling on Irish and British passports. Al Grassby was the responsible Minister at the time. I know that we had to telescope citizen qualification procedures to avoid Australia's losing a match on protest by North Korea. This is not good.

I believe that, in the present case, the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs would have told the Australian Soccer Federation what the score was. Last Saturday the sports pages of one newspaper carried the headline 'ASF will help Niven get citizenship for Socceroos'. I welcome people who want to play for Australia. I cannot understand why the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has not responded to the question I asked Senator Durack on Thursday of the week before last and has not defended its senior officers. I have no doubt that the Federation was told what the rules were. Let me relate a story on this aspect. Some honourable senators would know that on one occasion I had a violent conflict with none other than Mr Charles Perkins. It was nothing to do with immigration; it involved Aboriginal expenditure. I think the present Government Whip, Senator Kilgariff, was the other person caught in the cross-fire. I think Senator Shirley Walters was in the chair. Therefore Charlie Perkins and I do not get on too well. As late as last week at the Mount Isa airport Charlie Perkins said to me: 'Senator, I am all with you when you get stuck into Sir Arthur George'. There is a unity ticket between Charlie Perkins and myself. I would like an early answer to the question that I have raised in that respect. I hope what I have said on each matter will be taken on board.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this first reading debate to mention a matter which I think is of some importance to the Australian community at the moment. I refer to the air transport mess. I think one can describe it as no less than that. The Australian Democrats earnestly ask the Government to make an effort for once to sort out the air transport mess in Australia. I say at the outset that it is not a mess at the level of the staff, aircrews and support areas we have in this country. Thank goodness that at least we have employed in our aviation industry a body of people-in spite of all the provocations they suffer-who do an incredibly fine job. As I have said, this is in spite of the mess created by the Government in this area. Although, on reflection, I think it would be more accurate to lay the mess at the door of the Liberal Party of Australia as part of its endless subterranean process of support and financial wheeler-dealing. In almost every context one finds, by examination, that getting money for the Liberal Party turns out somehow to be a more important objective than the rights and wrongs of individual wishes.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, this situation was exacerbated recently by the Government's wicked-I call it no less than that-fiddling with the Commonwealth Electoral Act so that it could use the financial devices more and more with less and less accountability to the people in this country. That would be a real withdrawal from democracy. Recently, there has been the decision of the High Court of Australia. In its wisdom it said that the Government had a mandate in the future to lie as much as it wished and those lies are sanctioned by law. That decision exacerbates this problem even further. Let us be in no doubt about it. The Democrats know it. Businessmen who get telephone calls when an election campaign is coming up know it. They all come and tell me about it. The public know it. No wonder we have cynicism about the political process. I suggest that a good place to start remedying the situation would be to look at the whole air transport mess to try to get it straightened out.

The Australian Democrats would like to be in a position to ask the Holcroft Independent Public Inquiry into Domestic Air Fares to finish the job it started. But the situation is like Humpty Dumpty falling off the wall with all the King's horses and all the King's men and all the rest of it. There is no way that the Holcroft inquiry members, for whom I have a profound sympathy, can be expected in all self-respect to start where they left off nor, I suggest, could they be expected to have the motivation to do so after being treated with the cynicism and dishonesty that they have experienced. The Australian Democrats believe another investigation into this messy area is regrettably needed. Either a select committee of this Parliament or a royal commission should be established. The inquiry should ask: 'Does the two-airline system work?' Is it doing anything for Australia? Would deregulation be better? How much deregulation would be required? The Australian Democrats do not pretend to know the answers. We have had a bit of a look at the experience of deregulation in the United States of America and there are matters that are worrying.

The Airline Deregulation Act was enacted in the United States on 14 October 1978. Its major aim was to encourage, develop and maintain an air transportation system which relied on competitive market forces to determine the quality, variety and price of air services. I would have thought that this would have been very close to Liberal Party philosophy. It is certainly very close to Australian Democrats philosophy. I would have thought that the Liberal Party would be quite interested in that concept of fair market forces. We are always hearing about that in the Parliament and the Senate. Deregulation was strongly opposed in the United States by many of the smaller United States airlines which feared that the large, national lines would move in and take their previously protected territory away from them. However, the opposite happened. Because of a shortage of aircraft the major airlines tended to withdraw from low and medium traffic routes and use those extra aircraft on the major trunk routes.

The present situation, although far from chaotic as it has been described, is in some respects an improvement on the previous system. Indeed, extra competition has led to lower fares. That has been a plus and more people have been able to travel by air. The big losers, unfortunately, have been-this is very relevant to the Australian experience-small and medium-sized cities. Service to these cities has been reduced as airlines reallocate aircraft to the more significant and high-load trunk routes. This has struck a significant blow against the concept of decentralisation, as businessmen tend to shy away from locations which do not enjoy a full airline service. This has obvious and serious implications for Australia where, indeed, we have to consider decentralisation as a major issue of the future and as something with which we must really come to grips as soon as we can.

Some other relatively minor disadvantages flowing from deregulation in the United States include a considerable reduction in most airline profits which, it is fair to say, are partly accounted for by very high oil prices-this is a world-wide phenomenon-and a rationing problem of ground space and booking facilities et cetera at high demand airports. We believe that an inquiry is urgently needed which would take international experience into account and which would look at these kinds of points. The Democrats believe that total deregulation might not be a good thing. We are not in any way in favour of that for the reasons we have mentioned such as the safety aspects and other matters. But it would seem not unreasonable to examine whether two airlines are the right thing for Australia.

The two airlines agreement is properly the Airlines Agreement Act 1952. It has been in force in this country for nearly 30 years. That in itself is almost a good reason for its re-examination in the light of changing circumstances in the world and this was commented on in the Holcroft report. The report sought-indeed I think it is a fair statement-to sweep away the Menzies doctrine with its findings that 'the main presumption underlying the inauguration of the two-airline policy is not now applicable, if it ever was'. Whether it ever was is not relevant in 1981. The relevance today is something that I think an inquiry ought to look at. The Holcroft report exposed quite devastatingly the myth of competition between Trans-Australia Airlines and Ansett Airlines of Australia. It denounced the policy, in effect, as merely ensuring the 'preservation of a duopoly'-a horrible word but I think it is very demonstrable in this case. It preferred the solution of progressive deregulation of all but safety requirements.

It is fairly obvious in all the debate in this area that something along those lines is what we should be pursuing. The important point is that we should be pursuing it and not abandoning it. The debate has been cut off artificially in midstream. I think this is the most serious aspect. There seems to be very little doubt that the Holcroft inquiry was nobbled because of the Government's determination to have the new airlines agreement ratified in this parliamentary session, despite Government denials. Indeed, according to the article by Ali Cromie appearing in the Australian Financial Review of 9 March it became plain-if that report is at all accurate-that the Government had treated the Holcroft committee with extreme cynicism. Several points arise in this connection. There seems virtually no doubt that the Minister for Transport, Mr Hunt, gave everybody to understand that the report was due in June or July this year. The impetus for curtailing the inquiry almost certainly appears to have come from the Prime Minister (Mr Malcom Fraser). An article appearing in the Australian Financial Review of 4 March stated:

Another Western Australian Member said that at the meeting in the Prime Minister's office on November 26, the Prime Minister asked Mr Hunt when the Holcroft inquiry was due to report. Mr Hunt had replied 'June, July or thereabouts,' he said. The Prime Minister then said 'Ralph, tell them to report by January 31', the Western Australian Member said.
He did. The report continues:
This account of the meeting was verified-according to that reporter-by a number of Western Australian Members yesterday.

It is very interesting that there have been these significant leaks on procedures from Western Australian members of this Parliament. I say to Western Australian Government senators that the time has come for them to remember that they are senators for Western Australia in this place and that there is very great interest in Western Australia in their character and performance on this matter. They have so far gone to water. I am suggesting to them that time is running out. This is not an issue on which their electorate will take kindly their running to water. I think it is a matter that they will have to consider. They will have to consider their position honestly as senators for that State rather than as Government senators or any other kinds of senators. They will have to consider Western Australia's best interests. It seems to me that in relation to that State there is no doubt where its best interests lie. If one looks at the mess we must go back to the matter of parallel timetabling. I recall that nearly two years ago, on 26 September 1979, I asked the Minister then representing the Minister for Transport in this place, upon notice.

(1) Why has the Government not taken some effective action to end the dangerous, wasteful and inconvenient nuisance to the public which is involved in parallel timetabling between Ansett Airlines of Australia Limited and Trans-Australia Airlines Limited.

(2) Can the Minister, under Clause 5 of Schedule 3 of the Airlines Agreement Act 1952, use his discretion to refer the whole matter of parallel timetabling to the Rationalisation Committee established under that Act, in view of the fact that relative closeness in scheduling of flights between the airlines has given rise to the complaint that the services are not operated at intervals that adequately serve the public; if so, what action is proposed for the exercise of such discretion immediately so that the whole matter can be properly resolved.
At that time, I received in reply one of the most astounding pieces of double talk that I can remember. But the Minister said at the end of that reply:

I have since been advised that a joint working group has been established by the Airlines to devise schedules which reduce the incidence of parallel flights. Recent moves taken in regard to separated schedules on the Sydney-Canberra-Melbourne routes are considered only as a first step in this regard.

I would say that now, nearly two years later, any further steps that have been taken in this regard have certainly been very tiny and hesitant. We are still a long way from a rationally spread, safe system of scheduling. I have never been able to understand why this is the case. Why does the Government not exercise the powers that it has under the Act? Why can it not control the chaos that any honourable senator would have experienced if he had been at Canberra airport at 10 a.m. today when about four flights arrived at about the same time. In fact, there must have been grave safety problems, even air-space control problems, when aircraft are in the same air-space at the same time and when passengers have to wait for up to half an hour to get their baggage. It is absolutely unnecessary. It is an imposition on this society. That is another issue that I raise again.

Why cannot the sort of thing I am suggesting not be done? We would say that this is another instance of the Government's gutlessness, its complete subservience to present airline interests. The Government cannot even get that one right. It cannot step in and insist. Almost every member of Parliament, regardless of party, to whom I have mentioned this matter has said that the position is terrible and has asked why the situation cannot be rectified? I have never been able to understand why it should be the case, yet it happens. I suggest that it is a grave indictment of the Government's view of this whole area of industry. I also raise the situation of the more remote States and the philosophical question of whether we ought to consider this country as one country, as a country in which there should be some kind of subsidy paid to the more remote States or at least a fair recognition of the fact that aircraft operating over long distances operate more economically than over short distances.

I do not often agree with Sir Charles Court but in this case he at least sees the interests of his own State. I think it is essential for some means to be evolved so that the people in these parts of Australia who, through no fault of their own, are geographically isolated, should not have an additional financial burden placed on them. I suggest that it is completely unnecessary. It is a fact that to fly from Perth to Sydney is a big financial investment. Normally, when people have to make that flight it is for very good reasons. They just do not do it for pleasure; it is for urgent family, personal or business reasons. People on flights between Canberra and Sydney or Melbourne and Sydney perhaps do not have that motivation. The air fares involved for the businessman flying between Sydney and Melbourne are cheaper, anyway. He flies more cheaply than the person travelling between Sydney and Perth. I do not believe that the fact that Perth is further away justifies that. From a purely mechanical, cost accounting point of view it may do so, but from a nationalistic point of view, from the point of view of efficient business and efficient society in this country, it does not justify it in the least. I think that is also something that a committee should look at. Again, this is a matter for honourable senators from Western Australia to be concerned about.

The next point I wish to raise on this matter, concerns my constituents in New South Wales, and particularly in Sydney. It involves the vexed question of Sydney airport. I do not think, in view especially of modern scientific findings, on the effect of noise on human beings over a period, some of which are quite recent-they have been conducted over the last four or five months-that we can continue to say that we will have Sydney airport at Mascot forever. People from the Municipality of Rockdale have come to me in absolute desperation. School teachers from that area have come to me and said: 'Senator, it is no use. Every child who goes to school here will fail his exams and will not succeed because every time an aircraft goes over he or she looks out the window. Three minutes later the children are looking out the window again'. I have been told that there is not a great deal that can be done to stop them. They cannot habituate themselves to the terrible shattering roar over them all the time. Ninety thousand people live in the Rockdale municipality alone. The Major Airport Needs of Sydney Committee report of December 1979 recommended that we should have this nuisance increased by having a close spaced parallel runway established alongside the existing north-south runway at Mascot. This will be bedlam increased for probably 100,000 to 150,000 people who, through no fault of their own, live in these residential areas.

These noise problems are now a major political and social issue in those parts of Sydney, and with good reason. If we agreed with the MANS report, and I gather that the Government is considering this as a cheap alternative for the future-perhaps to the year 2000-we would increase the number of flight movements to 278,000 a year. That would represent an increase of 57 per cent on the present number of aircraft movements. Whilst that report states that the Committee is absolutely confident that modern engineering will make those aircraft quieter, the people of Rockdale, the Mayor of Rockdale and I do not believe it. I do not think that will happen.

I think that modern aircraft may well become noisier, because of the exigencies of the fuel situation, than they ever were. Certainly, more of them will be flying. We will have a situation in which, because of fuel exigencies, engine muffling may not be as satisfactory as it was before and in which a number of other factors such as flight paths will have to be taken into account. On the basis of the nuisance level alone, a re-examination of Sydney's airport should be seriously taken into account. This is a matter on which the initiative should be taken by the Federal Government. After all, the Commonwealth members of the MANS Committee pushed hard for the close spaced parallel runway next to the existing north-south runway to be the answer. The MANS report mentioned something which I think is almost lunatic in its absurdity. It recommended that land under aircraft flight paths in that part of Sydney should be rezoned. I wonder whether the members of that Committee stopped to think how many thousands of houses would have to be torn down to allow that rezoning to take place. We are talking about Australia's largest city now and that sort of monstrous statement in a report like that makes its credibility disappear.

TALK.START.PARA: —Were the houses there before the airport was built?

—That is utterly irrelevant. In fact, there were houses there, Rockdale is quite an old suburb. There were houses there a long time before the airport was built. Rockdale is close to the heart of Sydney. Some houses there are 60 or 70 years old.
—Kyeemagh was there before the War-before it was developed.
