—Yes, that is right. There is an option. There is a place where it could be put-Badgery's Creek in the Warragamba area. If we grasped the nettle now, we could solve the problem. The amount of environmental, social and residential disturbances there would be minimal. I do not say that it would not exist and my profound sympathy goes out to the people in that area, but I think that this has to be a better solution than what the MANS report suggested should be a contingency plan. Between 1980 and the year 2000 when passenger demand will grow by a factor of 2.7-in other words, it will be almost trebled-we cannot have a situation in which a major airport, catering both for international and national travel, should be allowed to exist in inner Sydney. As far as my constituents in Sydney are concerned, that is an important area in the airport mess, that the Government might also grasp. But surely these points indicate that everywhere one looks at this problem, except at the tremendous performance-safety and otherwise-of the actual individuals working in that industry, one finds trouble. I suggest that this is big trouble and that the Government ought to consider it. This is trouble about which a lot of people in Australia are concerned. This is, as we would say, a gut issue, and I commend it to the Government on that basis.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly on the motion for the first reading of a number of Bills before the Senate dealing with protection of the sea. As is the tradition in the Senate, because of other limits placed on us, this gives us as senators an opportunity to raise a wide-ranging number of issues which we consider to be important and of moment. The issue that I seek to raise this evening relates to charging by Telecom Australia. Today I raised in the Senate a question in relation to the charging of consumers by Telecom for international subscriber dialling if the consumers did not choose to have the service. I think that is totally outrageous and gives us a basis for looking at the whole rationale for Telecom and its future in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to give the Senate a rundown on the present system, which is shortly to become, we are told, the previous system. Today in my question I asked why, when a new system of accounting for international subscriber dialling calls is introduced into this country-it is long overdue, I might say-all subscribers will have to pay a penalty if they choose not to be connected to the ISD system. In reply the Minister indicated that Telecom was introducing a system of recording calls which would enable subscribers to check whether they had made international calls by direct dialling and that the introduction of that system and the machinery that goes with it would mean that all Telecom subscribers would have to pay a charge and those who chose to be barred from international dialling would have to pay a penalty charge. I suggest to the Senate that that is outrageous.

At the moment if subscribers want to query a total-and only a total is given-for trunkline calls, they have to pay a charge. I have been in the situation of requiring Telecom to give me a statement of charges for trunkline calls. I have had to pay a fee for that and, whilst there is assistance for members of parliament in paying telephone accounts, it does not cover that fee. It is, I will agree, a small amount, but when I have received such a detailed statement I have certainly found quite a number of errors in the charging by Telecom for trunkline calls on my telephone. The errors have fallen into three categories. The first relates to when I have made a call from my telephone service and requested that it be charged to the Federal Members Authority system, which means it should not appear on my bill at all. Some trunk operators have not properly billed the calls and they have appeared on my personal account by mistake. The second category relates to when others have made telephone calls from my service and have used credit cards. Instead of the call being charged to the credit card, it has been charged to my account. When Telecom has been queried it has had a record of the fact that such calls should have been charged to a credit card but were not and appeared on my bill.

The third category relates to calls which should never have been charged to my telephone at all. I must say that there is not a large penalty for me personally in this because I can have something done about those incorrectly charged calls and I have the alternative of diverting to an FMA charge those calls which should have been charged thus in the first place. Nevertheless, I had to pay a charge for extracting from Telecom a statement of telephone call charges that should never have been billed to me. It is a small charge but a matter of principle. I think of those subscribers who have to pay all their own trunkline charges, but who would reasonably ask Telecom for a statement of charges and find them to be incorrect.

In the last two years a number of such cases have come to my notice because they have been connected with me. I have had access, by favour, to someone's private telephone, have made a call on business and have asked for it to be charged to my FMA number. Some of those telephone calls tend to be rather lengthy. I know of at least two cases of individual subscribers who have been horrified by their trunk call charges and have asked for a statement of the charges; and it has transpired that the reason for the high trunk charges is that calls which I made on their telephone service and which should have been charged to my FMA number have not been so charged but have been charged to them individually. This raises with me the serious worry as to how many other people who granted me the favour of using their private telephones, on my assurance that the calls would be charged to my FMA number because they were on parliamentary business, have paid telephone accounts that they should not have paid because they were not properly charged.

In those two cases the people asked for statements of their trunk calls and queried with me whether the call charged to them, which they did not make, was one that I made. I have verified that and it has subsequently been charged to my Federal Members Authority. How many people whose telephones I have used in good faith have subsequently paid bills that they should not have paid because of Telecom's sloppiness? Those who have discovered the error have had to pay a Telecom charge for the favour of being given the information to acquaint Telecom of its own errors. They have had to pay a charge to receive information to enable them to right their telephone accounts. That is the present system.

I turn to the subject of metered calls. There have been many complaints in the Senate about the method of charging for STD calls. I have been a victim of this system. The simple situation is that in the past subscribers who have used a telephone for STD purposes, and who have received a charge for metered calls which they consider to be overinflated, have had no come back at all if they have used STD in the period for which they were billed. I will relate my own circumstance. My own telephone bills, including rental, have ranged between $70 and $100. I do not make many telephone calls from home; the telephone is used mainly as a convenience for incoming calls. I do not spend very much time in my home because of the demands of my jobs and I live on my own. After some years of $70 to, at the most, $120 six-monthly accounts, I received to my horror in January 1976 a bill which showed that I had to pay almost $1,200-ten times more than the maximum I have ever paid for a telephone account. This covered a period when I was Deputy Opposition Whip and had made STD calls on two occasions which I could identify very clearly in terms of the dates and the length of time that those STD calls could have occurred on given days. But because I had used my telephone for subscriber trunk dialling and because I had not kept a record of the actual length of those calls, after two years of arguing the toss with Telecom I had to pay. That was at a time, I might say, when members' metered calls were not paid by the Government.

A large proportion of the account was paid out of public funds but as a matter of principle I was arguing the account because it had to be grossly wrong. The State accountant for Telecom in Queensland called me at my office one day and I suffered the indignity of being asked very rudely by him whether I was stalling on the account because I wanted the Government to pay it. I told him that in any event the Government-that is, the taxpayer-would pay a major part of it. The point was not whether I paid it or whether the taxpayer paid it but whether Telecom had any right to charge it. In the next two years my telephone accounts came back to normal. By the end of the two years my accounts were less than $100 for a six-month period. They have remained thus. Nevertheless, I was in the position that all Telecom subscribers are in eventually: I had to pay the account or lose my telephone service. In Australia there is nowhere else to take one's business if one thinks one is being charged for a telephone service one did not get.

In the course of the many arguments that have raged whether Telecom is charging correctly for metered calls, we have all been aware of the machinery available which would enable a proper recording of STD calls made from an individual telephone service. However, Telecom has not introduced this service and there have been debates in the Senate as to how much revenue Telecom would lose if the service were introduced allowing individual subscribers to check the metered calls made and thus to challenge them by the same method as in the case of trunk calls if they thought they had not made those calls and could give reasonable proof that they had not made them. It appears that reasonable proof in the checking of booked trunk calls is to check with the person whose number was dialled to see whether he or she received the call and that the call was made on the date and from the service of the person to whom the call is charged.

On the other hand, international subscriber dialling has had to be connected to individual subscriber's telephones by request. There has been a catch for those people who have requested the connection. Those who have the international subscriber dialling service connected to their telephone and who believed they were overcharged have no come back at all about the total charge appearing against the ISD item. Whilst it would appear from the Telecom bill that certain overseas telephone calls had been made, Telecom would never check with the number dialled overseas to verify that the call had been made. Telecom would check against the booked local trunkline calls but would not under any circumstances check it against international calls. If the subscriber had been foolish enough to have the ISD service connected he would find that he had no comeback at all about any unfortunate overcharging that showed up in his telephone account. We all know that overseas telephone calls are charged at a very high rate for each minute and the complaints about such charges are many. There is, therefore, a situation where some charges, but not all, could be verified.

Telecom has had available to it for a long time the machinery which would have avoided these difficulties with subscriber trunk dialling and international subscriber dialling. Telecom has also had in its employ a large number of inspectors who were supposed to check on the honesty of Telecom employees in regard to complaints that certain technicians who had access to subscribers telephone services were abusing that access. The inspectors were supposed to examine those complaints. Many times on Senate Estimates committees, I have asked questions on the number of inspectors employed, the salaries paid and the number of charges brought against Telecom employees. From memory, on the most recent inquiry I made, which is now several years ago, there were then 49 inspectors paid, a very high total salaries bill and no charges had ever been brought against any employees of Telecom for abuse of access to subscriber telephone services. This is despite serious charges made by former employees of Telecom and by sections of the media about the abuse of access to subscriber services. Those serious and on occasions what appeared to be well-based charges were not investigated. Several years ago, 49 inspectors were employed to investigate abuses but no charges were ever levelled. This is what Telecom told us some time ago.

At the time when this subject arose for discussion in the Senate perhaps it would have been appropriate for a parliamentary committee to investigate the methods of charging by Telecom-Telecom told us that it was going to introduce this machinery available to it which would enable a recording of all metered calls so that all subscribers could have available to them access to information on calls for which they were being charged. It appeared to me from the answer that I received today in the Senate that what we were being told is that the installation of this ISD service is to be paid for by all subscribers whether they need it or not. There has been no indication that the system of recording and charging booked trunk calls is to be changed. Apparently one is still to pay the account even when the statement of account is incorrect. We are now told that with subscriber trunk dialling we will be able to get details of calls made by direct dialling within Australia. This is years after that service has been available.

What is the cost of this proposal? At present STD is automatically available on all telephone services. Certain telephone subscribers require that access to STD be barred. Large organisations require that a certain number of extensions passing through a switchboard have bars placed on them so that not all those telephone extensions can take STD calls. I think that we would all understand the reasons for that requirement. That has been a selective barring. It applies in respect of the Parliament House telephone system. Now ISD is to be available on the same basis and if the subscriber does not want to be charged for international subscriber dialling he must request that this be barred. I emphasise that the present situation with STD is that it would normally be available on all private subscribers' numbers. If subscribers do not use STD, they will not be charged for STD calls. If the subscriber can claim and verify on a reasonable basis that he never makes STD calls, he is excused from those charges. ISD is now to be made available on the same basis and simply because Telecom is bringing in a recording system which it should have had in operation years ago in relation to STD and ISD we are all now to pay if we do not want access to the system.

It was not suggested before that individual subscribers who did not want to use STD-certainly I am one of them now-should have had to pay a fee for not having access. It was not suggested when ISD was first introduced that if we did not choose to have access we would have to pay. Because ISD is to be available on the same basis as STD, now we must pay not to have access to international dialling. It is not good enough, according to Telecom, that the service is not used. We must positively prevent Telecom giving us that service and we must pay for that action. It was never felt that there was any need to charge for offering to people a barring for STD. As far as I am aware, unless they had been caught badly by a Telecom account of the type about which I recounted my experience earlier and sought an STD bar, most subscribers would be unaware that STD barring was available. Those who were aware of the barring device were those who encountered it in a work situation with a multi-telephone extension service. Why has this access to barring been introduced only in relation to ISD for what is claimed to be a moderate charge?

I could not care what the initial fee to be charged will be-whether it is moderate or large. A principle is at stake. I do not care whether it costs 20c, 40c or $40 to get a statement of trunk line calls for which one should never have been charged in the first place. The simple fact is that Telecom has a monopoly on this type of telecommunication in Australia. It is a statutory corporation in a monopolistic system and protected in its monopoly by the Government. There are a number of other what I consider essential services carried out by statutory corporations. I name organisations such as Trans-Australia Airlines, the Australian Broadcasting Commission and Qantas Airways Limited. They have not resiled from competition with private enterprise. It has been necessary to have some regulation of the industry within which each organisation operates. I suggest it is time that the Government seriously addressed itself to looking at opening up to private enterprise the telecommunications services over which Telecom currently has a monopoly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you seriously suggesting that in relation to the telephone system?
—I am absolutely seriously suggesting it.
—In relation to the telephone system?

—I am absolutely seriously suggesting it, senator. I am certainly one who is aware of the disadvantages of allowing private enterprise into a difficult structure such as we have with telecommunications in my State of Queensland. I do not support a system-
—Have you any idea what the cost of that would be?

—The honourable senator should just be quiet. I do not support an arrangement which enables private enterprise to pick the eyes out of the profitable area but I am saying that there have been other areas in which Government services have been considered to be necessary-I have named them-and in which it has been possible for statutory corporations, government backed to operate alongside private enterprise. I think it is time that the Government seriously considered that in relation to Telecom. We have the worst of both worlds in this situation. We have a statutory corporation in a monopolistic system claiming protection because it has to provide a service to areas which are uneconomic. I accept that because in my State of Queensland those services are essential and I accept that at this present stage it appears to be necessary to have a government backed enterprise which is able to provide such services. I also point out that in this same State we have difficulty with air communications. It has been possible to reach a situation whereby an air service can be provided by more than one organisation although part of the service is uneconomic. The Government ought to consider this.

SPEECH.PARA: We, the supporters of the Liberal Government, cannot live with a monopoly which can charge for services never given and which can charge for providing a statement of account which proves that the services were never given and the consumer has no comeback. Those who feel and cannot prove that they have been overcharged by Telecom have absolutely nowhere else to turn. If they have been overcharged many of them, I believe, have a genuine case which ought to be accepted; but they are told: 'Pay up or else lose your service'.

In the case of overcharging on metered calls which I described earlier, the alternative that Telecom has given to date has been to install at a six-monthly rental rate a metering device. If a subscriber installs this device and there is still a discrepancy between the calls metered by it and the calls metered by Telecom the subscriber has to pay for the calls as metered by Telecom. Never mind that one is paying rental on Telecom's equipment to meter the charges and that its equipment, either the stuff installed in one's home or at the exchange, is faulty, one has to pay the charge that Telecom claims one should pay. One has no argument about it because Telecom is a monopoly. If Telecom cannot provide a more satisfactory service to consumers, it ought to be in competition. I think it has been amply shown over the years that Telecom cannot provide a service with which the consumer can be satisfied. Consumers cannot be satisfied that they have received the service for which they have been charged. A proposal to charge a fee to those people who choose not to have access to a service surely highlights the absurdity of it all. If Telecom seriously intends to proceed with this proposal then I think its position in the market-place ought to be very closely examined. The history of Telecom, its reliability, its sensitivity to consumers, its willingness to admit that it is wrong, is very poor indeed and it has brought on itself, through its own insensitivity, a questioning of its basic function in Australia. I say that without any blush, Senator Button. In all the years that I have been a member of the Liberal Party I may from time to time have examined why, and it is organisations such as Telecom which have persuaded me why. If we lived in a society in which we were subject to charges for services by organisations such as this, it would be a very frustrating and unrewarding society. Many thousand telephone subscribers have faced the situation of being totally convinced that they were being charged for services which they had not received and they have received absolutely no consideration at all in a reasonable situation.

In respect of overcharging on subscriber trunk dialling, it has been quite common for Telecom employees to say to elderly people: 'Oh, but you are old; you don't remember the telephone calls you have made'. Even if they had made claims that they rarely if ever used STD the fact that they were elderly or pensioners was held to be of sufficient proof that they could not possibly know better than the equipment which was demonstrably not totally satisfactory. Certainly there are cases of those who have operated with the system-

TALK.START.PARA: —The family sometimes uses the telephone and the elderly people don't know.
—I suggest the honourable senator should stick to subjects he knows something about and I know that would vastly limit him.
—I have listened to you enough, criticising the employees of Telecom when you know nothing about it.
—Order!
—Worker bashing again.
— Order!

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. It is extraordinary how there are those who cannot hear anything other than in the terms in which they are conditioned to hear. I am not bashing all the employees of Telecom at all. What I am saying is that reasonable cases have been made of individuals employed by Telecom who have abused their position. Why else would Telecom employ 49 inspectors allegedly to enforce a law to catch dishonest employees? Why would 49 inspectors be employed state-wide if Telecom did not believe that there was some reasonable basis for such employment? If Telecom is employing those inspectors without any reasonable basis as to why they are necessary, Telecom ought to explain that too because the consumers are paying again for a service they are not getting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Sen R.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has already been said that it is traditional to take the opportunity on a motion for the first reading of a money Bill to speak on a variety of subjects. Honourable senators have certainly covered several subjects this evening. I take this opportunity to raise a subject which is causing me great concern and which should be causing the Government more concern than it is. I refer to the unemployed young people in our society. My concern stems from the proposal, following the October election last year, that the Government intended to cut the unemployment benefit for young people under the age of 18 years. My concern also is that we are not even aware of what is happening in our society because of unemployment among our young people. Practically no money is being spent on research to find out just what these people who are unemployed are feeling and their reaction to the society which virtually has rejected them.

SPEECH.PARA: On 19 December last year in the West Australian a very moving letter from a person living in Sorrento was published in the Letters to the Editor section. The person claimed that he was usually apathetic when it came to government policy but he felt at that stage that he could no longer privately contain his anger at the Government's shortsighted and dehumanised policy toward youth unemployment. The letter went on to read:

Increasingly, as I voice my views among my acquaintances, I am struck by the number who share my opinion. The silent majority, among whom I none too proudly number myself, are not indifferent; rather, individually, they feel powerless to influence the Government.

Combined effort by the mass of people must force the Government into action; and who in the community can stand indifferent? As actors we play many different parts-friends, neighbours, workmates, uncles, aunts, parents and grandparents. As a community we are involved and touch each other.

Perhaps your child is employed-but what of his best friend, his mate that dratted kid who's been arriving at inopportune moments on Sunday morning since he was six, letting in flies, walking in sand and helping himself to the food? Directly or indirectly we are all involved.
The fight against inflation must not be won at the expense of our kids. The cost is too dear.

I commend the writer of that letter. I think it sets out very clearly the effects that unemployment, particularly as it relates to young people in our society, is having on those people who were perhaps once apathetic and who now are part of that silent majority gradually finding its voice. We also find that a number of small reports-articles in psychiatric magazines and medical journals-are coming to light which show that individuals are doing some research on the effects of unemployment on young people. One article that I read recently was by Dr Robert Kosky, the psychiatric superintendent at the Child Psychiatry Services division of the Mental Health Services in Western Australia who is also a visiting psychiatrist at the Princess Margaret Hospital for children in Perth. Dr Kosky, in the light of the very high unemployment in the 15 to 19 year age group and on the basis of his clinical work, has made some observations which were printed in the Australian Family Physician of December 1980. The article was entitled 'Unemployment/mental health of adolescents'. I do not intend to read the whole article. I will seek leave at a later stage to have it incorporated in Hansard for the attention of honourable senators. It is important to record some of what Dr Kosky said. He stated:
There is an astonishing lack of research into the mental health of young people who experience long term unemployment, although this aspect is often referred to in sociological studies.

I ask honourable senators to pay particular attention to those very descriptive words that Dr Kosky used to describe the feelings of these unemployed people. For instance, he used words such as depressed, angry, powerless, impotent, bored, lonely, frustrated and rejected. Those feelings are all very real and it is all very sad that not only do we not provide enough money for research into these areas but also we do not even bother to find out just how those people who are affected most by high unemployment are coping. Dr Robert Kosky said:

There is an astonishing lack of research into the mental health of young people who experience long term unemployment . . . It is possible to make out a prima facie case that unemployment is associated with poor mental health from a number of isolated studies-
Juvenile delinquency in South Australia was associated with unemployed status of offenders and offenders' parents.

The rate of attempted suicide in unemployed persons in a large Victorian country town was twelve times the average area rate. In Blacktown Municipality of New South Wales, it was estimated that 30-40 per cent of people attempting suicide were unemployed.

Of 15-24-year-olds who were treated for the first time by the Mental Health Authority (Victoria) and who were unemployed, 11 per cent were diagnosed as alcoholic. The majority of 15,000 people under 25 years, estimated to be homeless in Melbourne in 1978 were said to be unemployed.

Unemployed persons reported more respiratory illnesses, more migraines, more blackouts and more irritability, than employed persons in a South Australian study. Twenty-one per cent of Community Youth Support System, and 35 per cent of Commonwealth Employment Service clients reported 'often feeling depressed'. None of these studies assesses personal mental health adequately. Nor do they decide between cause and effect.
Dr Kosky asks:
What happens to young people who cannot get work? What do they feel?

My clinical work brings me into contact with many adolescents who cannot find work. A dozen of these I have interviewed regularly over a period of one to three years in each case. I would like to describe what I have observed.

They all started their search for employment on leaving school with confidence and optimism. As successive attempts fo find a job proved fruitless, they got angry. They reckoned they had been deceived by school and, when their friends found work (often through the personal influence of parents) they felt unfairly treated. Still they showed courage to go on applying for jobs, some over a hundred times. 'It was like', said one, 'having each morning to climb into the ring with Muhammad Ali knowing that . . . well . . . boom'. Suddenly, they felt let down-powerless to do anything about their situation, impotent in the face of seemingly endless rejections of their offered services. Overton has captured this feeling in his cartoons, reproduced here by kind permission of the editor of Nation Review.
I suggest to all honourable senators that they look at them. Whilst they are in cartoon form, I assure honourable senators that they are too real to be funny. Dr Kosky continued:

The unemployed person had little spare cash and could not afford to keep up socially with his or her friends. They parted company-a further blow to the self-esteem of the unemployed person. Now, instead of going out and enjoying social activities, the jobless person sat around home all day watching television (often quite oblivious to the program content), bored, lonely and frustrated. At this stage some became very depressed and this was in marked contrast to their earlier and normal selves. One tried to kill himself, several others started abusing drugs and alcohol apparently to escape feelings of despair.

This phase lasted several months before contact was begun with others in a similar position-often met as drinking companions. They then linked up with other unemployed and a happier period began. Activities were enjoyed again and television was eschewed. But I had noticed a change in the personalities of the people I was seeing. In place of those personal aspirations for their future which they had previously cherished, they now talked about having new ideals and personal philosophies. These, it seemed to me, did not have much to do with their own unique personal qualities or experiences but were, rather, products of their new group experiences- with other long-term unemployed persons. However they en- abled the person to take a renewed interest in life.

The first phases of anger and despair were reactions to the experiences of rejection. Obtaining work brought a return to normal mental health. However once the group phase had settled in, changes were difficult to reverse. The young person appeared to lose interest in working, or if work were obtained, to lack any enthusiastic commitment, tire quickly of it, and hanker for return to jobless status.
I want to look more closely at why this might be so . . .

In adolescence the two major psychological tasks are the establishment of independence and the consolidation of a sense of personal identity. It should be clear that unemployment can cut directly across the accomplishment of both of these tasks.
Dr Kosky goes on to say:

However the jobless adolescent must turn from the parents to the State for the money to buy the necessities of life. The alternatives are to remain dependent on parents in some way, or to engage in crime.

To me, the most important part of that problem is crystal clear. Unemployment is of such a magnitude and of such a destructive nature to our young people that only real and long term solutions should be sought. In the light of anguish of the majority of young unemployed, the Government's reported proposal to cut the unemployment benefit can be regarded only as cynical and distasteful-cynical as an attempt to merely reduce the number of people officially unemployed while making no real impact on unemployment and distasteful in that the Fraser Government has turned on a section of our society which is not politically powerful and which it has systematically over the years, denigrated by encouraging the use of the term 'dole bludgers'.

I do not know how many honourable senators received the questionnaire that I had on my desk some two weeks ago when last we were in this place but, from memory, it came from an institute of learning in South Australia. The questionnaire asked me to express my opinion on a number of matters relating to unemployment. Among all the questions, it asked, something to the effect: How did I personally view dole payments? I object wholeheartedly to the use of the word 'dole'. It is an insulting word. The people who receive that benefit are receiving an unemployment benefit. We do not ever suggest that aged people received an age dole. Yet if honourable senators look at the word in the dictionary, they will see that its meaning could allow it to be used in that sense. 'Dole' means a payment from charity or a payment by the State as a benefit, so any benefit that a person receives could be considered to be dole. But this is all part and parcel of the conditioning we have had in our society over the last few years-this conditioning of setting Australian against Australian, the employed against the unemployed and the trade unionist against the employer. We now find that it is common even for unemployed people to talk about the dole. They talk about the Commonwealth Employment Service as the unemployment office and, as I say, they talk about their unemployment benefit as the dole and they do so with what appears to be some sense of pride or achievement. They have had to do so in order to react against what the Government is doing.

It concerns me that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr Viner) think that they can balance their books at the expense of our kids. The last time I stood in this place and referred to young people as kids I received a number of letters from people saying that kids were goats. Well, I have two kids of my own. Fortunately, one is employed but the other is still at school and I have to recognise the distinct possibility that with the situation that pertains in this country at the moment he may be very lucky ever to be employed. He is my kid and I want the best for him as I am sure most honourable senators in this place want the best for theirs. But, as the letter which I quoted at the beginning of my speech said, the cost is too dear if in actual fact we allow the Prime Minister and the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs to balance their books purely and simply at the expense of those people.

There have been a number of reports of various studies that have been done on this matter. In the Age of 21 January this year another study was reported which is claimed to be one of the first to evaluate scientifically the emotional problems of the unemployed. It sampled 313 people in Melbourne-not a very large sample, I am sure honourable senators will agree, but probably once again all that could be done given the possible financial limitations of this necessary research area. In that study researchers found that of the 169 unemployed-mostly under 35 years of age-37 per cent showed a dangerous level of anxiety. Sixteen per cent needed urgent treatment. The study described such anxiety levels as comparable to those of maximum security prisoners in Pentridge. That is an incredible statement to be made. A high percentage of unemployed people had anxiety levels similar to those of maximum security prisoners in Pentridge, a Melbourne University study has found. The report in the Age went on to say:

The study was conducted by Dr Alan Hughes, senior lecturer in political sociology at Melbourne University, and Mr Talisgolis, a registered psychologist and a lecturer in political psychology at La Trobe University. Dr Hughes said the study indicated that anxiety neurosis, with symptoms such as a sickly appearance, hand tremor, speech hesitation and restless body movement, was at a ''dangerous level among the unemployed''.

He said people suffering from anxiety neurosis would be unlikely to find employment even if jobs were freely available. In most cases, they would also be unable to get psychiatric help. Dr Hughes said it was common for a young person unemployed for a long period to pass through four stages: financial problems because of a failure to find a job; an inability to maintain friendships because of the stigma of being unemployed, accompanied by distrust and despair; the growth of uncontrollable anxiety, with depression, suicide, in extreme cases.
. . . . He said many young unemployed did not reply when asked to describe their lives. ''They can no longer make sense of their situation or describe it with any hope,'' Dr Hughes said.
''The questions people are asking themselves are: 'Will I get a job?' in contrast to 'What sort of job will I get?' and 'Will I hold this job?' rather than 'Where will it take me?''

. . . . Dr Hughes said that if the Federal Government moved to cut unemployment benefits to people under 18, it would have a disastrous effect on the young unemployed. 'It is imperative for the Federal Government to reconsider it,' he said.
As we have not heard any mention of it over the last few weeks I hope the Government has reconsidered it. The article continues:
''To suggest taking away their unemployment assistance would lead to personal tragedy for which the politicians would be directly responsible.''

So clearly, cutting the unemployment benefit to young people is no answer, especially when the Government is in no position to offer employment. The cold hard fact is that unemployment is not easing. One does not have to be an economist or a mathematician to find that; one has to look only at the reports that regularly flood across the desks of members of parliament. Alan Austin said in an article in the Nation Review in October that although 'unemployment has grown marginally, evidence suggests that the Government's drive to remove unemployed and disabled people from the registers may have had a lot to do with it'. The Age editorial of Friday, 23 January this year asked, 'What work, Mr Viner?', in reply to the Minister's statement of the day before that there was employment around if people were motivated to find it. The editorial had to point out to the Minister the reality of the situation. It stated:

In December 430,000 Australians were looking for work, one-third of them teenagers, but only about 30,000 jobs were looking for workers. Most young people who are on the dole are unemployed because there are not nearly enough jobs for them, not because they are stupid or lazy or because the education system has failed them.

Commonwealth Employment Service figures show that unemployment is still rising. Its figures indicate that in December last year there were at least 20,000 more people without jobs than there were in December 1979. According to the Australian Bureau of Statistics unemployment for juniors for December was 146,200. More than 21 per cent of the junior work force do not have a job. In the West Australian of 16 January this year a report stated that the unemployment rate for juniors did not fall below 16.7 per cent during 1980. That is a disgraceful statement to be made on the part of a government that professes to be concerned about those young unemployed people in our community. But those official figures do not take into account the hidden unemployment which would substantially raise the numbers out of work officially.

Dr Kosky, in his article, is obviously alluding to certain sections of those hidden unemployed when he refers to unemployed women and to some of the serious ramifications of the position they find themselves in. I repeat that this article is by Dr Robert Kosky who is a Psychiatrist Superintendent of the Child Psychiatry Division of the Mental Health Services of Western Australia. He is also Visiting Psychiatrist at the Princess Margaret Hospital for Children in Perth. He is obviously a very feeling person. He is obviously a person who recognises that the problem in our society does not stop with the young unemployed; it continues on through to the societal problems which are created by their very unemployment. Dr Kosky, in referring to women, says:

The position of women in relation to unemployment presents special problems which have not yet been clearly defined. While it is generally accepted that women have as much right to work as men and to receive equivalent remuneration, in practice this not yet the case. Furthermore, it is often stated that women should keep out of the work force in the present difficult employment situation. What effect these opposing forces have on young women seeking work from school is not known.

Bearing in mind the high and rising rate of attempted suicide in young females, the high incidence of depressive disorders in women compared with men, the recent increased incidence of failed marriages, it might be argued that women are seeking to escape the competition for jobs and the conflicting attitudes about their place in the work force, by contracting early unhappy and unsuccessful marriages.

Dr Kosky takes part of that quotation from 'Trends in Suicidal Behaviour and its Management' published in the Australian-New Zealand Journal of Psychiatry 1980 by Goldney and Burvil. His comments, as he admits, are speculative, but I would think that the majority of the people in this place and in the other place have a fair amount of contact with the unemployed and could hardly express surprise at that appraisal. It is these human aspects of the tragedy of the young unemployed that I believe politicians and others who influence the destinies of the young should constantly keep in mind. We find, unfortunately, that the Government tends to sweep them under the carpet. I get the impression that the Government would like to ignore the problem in the hope that it will eventually go away. One of the things that it has to recognise is that it is just not going to disappear. The number of unemployed young people in our society will continue to grow until such time as the Government takes positive action and really makes its presence felt in this area.

Some welfare groups have warned that the Federal Government's proposal to discontinue the unemployment benefit for 16 and 17-year-olds could heighten problems associated with homelessness, crime, alcohol and drug abuse, and possibly even the destruction of the family unit. I would say that a large number of families have already found themselves virtually destroyed either because they are affected by young unemployed people in their unit or because one of the parents has suddenly become unemployed. There are any number of refuges for unemployed in all States-the Jesus People Inc. in Western Australia, the Reverend Ted Noffs's Wayside Chapel in Sydney. There are such refuges throughout Melbourne-in the eastern and western suburbs-and in Brisbane, the Northern Territory, South Australia and Tasmania. They are all there and they will all tell us much the same thing-that after a short period on unemployment benefit, being rejected time after time for jobs for which they apply, young people particularly go through four stages, becoming more and more depressed and more and more susceptible to crime, alochol and drug abuse, and destruction of the family unit. Dr Kosky states:
As a group of individuals who are disallowed full social acceptance, the unemployed group becomes stigmatized. They are then identified, by outsiders, in terms of stereotypes.

As I said earlier, the Prime Minister and the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs have unmercifully labelled sections of the unemployed as dole bludgers. Senator Mason spoke earlier about travel by aircraft in Australia. He put a different interpretation on it. I have some of my most interesting contacts with people on my very long flights from Perth to Canberra and Canberra to Perth every week, which, incidentally, take me almost two days. I am concerned at the growing number of well educated, possibly even well meaning, people in our society who have now latched on to the term, 'dole bludger'. As far as the majority of people are concerned any young person who does not have a job, whether it is because he or she cannot get a job really is not important, is a dole bludger. When the Governor-General opened the new session of Parliament in this chamber in November last year he expressed a concern for unemployed people, but the Government has done very little about unemployed people, especially unemployed young people, in the last five years. It has had five years-almost five and a half years-in office and it has still not done anything about the situation. Dr Kosky states:
Of course, these stereotypes represent projections onto the group by the outsiders and have little basis in the actual individuals who make up the group.
They are then identified by outsiders in terms of the stereotype that I have already mentioned. Dr Kosky states:
. . .'dole bludger' is familiar enough. Others are 'aggressive rebels against society' or 'a moral cancer in the community' or the paternalistic 'problem kids who need saving from themselves'. . .

Unfortunately it appears likely that these very stereotypes are used in bonding the individuals in the group. All, as individuals, felt impotent. The group acceptance provides strength by increasing the individual's self esteem.
What of the possible effects? Dr Kosky explains one. He states:
. . . the values inherent in the stereotypes are inverted. Work becomes self-debasement, poverty or virtue, rags a fashion.

Whilst work was initially sought as a means of acceptance into society it may now mean giving up the comfortable acceptance of the group which has nourished a wounded self-esteem. Dr Kosky further states:

To take the first alternative invites the possibility of further rejections, like those previously experienced, with no sure knowledge that, having turned ones back on the group, one will be accepted back if the need arises.

Mr Fraser has said that the Government owes young people more than an inadequate schooling and the dole. At one stage he asked 'Would you leave them the option of just getting unemployment benefit?'. I have to say: 'No, Mr Fraser, I would not leave them in limbo on a meagre $36 a week and I certainly would not consider cutting that benefit and claiming that it would ensure the youth of Australia a better preparation for the workforce by forcing them back to school'. More schooling will really produce only a more educated group of unemployed. The Government just does not seem to appreciate that the jobs are not there. An article in the National Times of 25 to 31 January has rightly pointed out that for the large majority the lack of the paltry $36-which, incidentally, is nearly $30 below the poverty line-would not cause these young people to return to school. The article states:

Many assume that the parent who takes a child from school to put him or her to work is a figure who died with the Dickens novel and the Great Depression. They forget that one in five Australian family income units are still at or below the Henderson poverty line (a figure that is growing worse, according to a recent Australian Bureau of Statistics income survey). And one in 10 families is headed by a lone parent who is often desperate for a teenage child to supplement the family income and even to take over as breadwinner.

Those students, those young people belonging to those low income, below the poverty line families, are forced from school by poverty. Forcing them to stay at school by non-payment of the unemployment benefit only places more of those family units at risk. I believe that it is totally callous and unreasonable to expect families already living below the poverty line to shoulder the entire responsibility of young unemployed members of their families. Within that context, this is the real poverty that exists in this country. It is clear that the Government has reneged on the statement of the Governor-General, in his speech in this chamber on 25 November 1980, when he expressed concern with the human dimensions of the serious issue of youth unemployment. How long after that statement was made by the Governor-General did the Government come up with the bright idea of suspending the payment of unemployment benefit to those young people who had left school before they were 18 years of age?

The Bureau of Statistics figures that I referred to earlier showed that of the 1.7 million income units below the poverty line more than 200,000 are living on less than $40 a week. Young unemployed who are not at home clearly fall into this category, that is, if they are claiming the benefit. We may ask: What of the unemployed who have left school through choice, those whom Mr Fraser may describe as dole bludgers? The National Times article states that a study conducted by the Outer Western Sydney Regional Council for Social Development among unemployed in the suburbs of Blacktown, Mount Druitt, Penrith, St Marys and the Blue Mountains found that 25 per cent of unemployed youth left school because they did not like it. It continued:
Many, however, do not claim-
Once again we find that reprehensible phrase-
the dole.

A number of studies, including the Norgard report on the Commonwealth Employment Service of 1977 which was commissioned by this Government, have found that about one-third of all unemployed do not register with the CES. The article in the National Times of 25 to 31 January from which I have already quoted continues:

A great many youth who leave school for reasons besides poverty don't claim the dole because of the stigma attached to it. So withholding payment is hardly likely to force them back into the classroom.

To break out of the vicious circle we need the real economic recovery that the Fraser Government has been promising us for nearly six long years. I do not believe it is any longer any good for the Government to complain about what the people of Australia are failing to do.

We have gone through a phase where it was the consumers who were responsible for the lack of economic return. Then it was business which was responsible for the lack of economic return. I do not believe it is any longer any good for the Government to seek to indoctrinate the Australian community to advance Australia. I do not believe that it is any good indulging in grandiose talk about new youth schemes and a brighter future for the young unemployed. I believe it is an indecent attempt to form some economic recovery by cooking the books and fiddling with the numbers when all the facts clearly point to the Government's continuing failure to stimulate that economic recovery. Conscripting kids back to school is not the answer.

I question when Mr Fraser will show us that his Government is prepared to develop a serious approach to the tragic problem and the social consequences of youth unemployment. If he is serious about using the school system to alleviate youth unemployment, his record certainly does not show it. As I have said, he has had the last five or six years to implement his educational programs designed to relieve unemployment. They have not done so. The question remains: When will the Government fulfil its promise? I remind honourable senators of a promise made in 1975 prior to the election at a time when Mr Fraser was the caretaker Prime Minister of this country. He said: 'Every person who wants to work will have a job.' I have cited figures already tonight. Hundreds of thousands of people who want to work cannot get a job because of the callous and extreme attitude being expressed by this Government, particularly to those people who fall into that 16 to 18 years age group. I seek leave to incorporate a report by Dr Robert Kosky, the child psychiatrist from the Mental Health Services of Western Australia, from which I have been reading at various stages of my speech. I notified the Deputy President who was in the chair earlier that it would be my intention at the end of my speech so to do. I have not shown it to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume). I do so now. I seek leave to have the report incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The report read as follows-
Unemployment and the mental health of adolescents
On 1 February 1980, there were 442,400 people registered as unemployed in Australia. One third of these were aged between 15 and 19 years. (Australian Bureau of Statistics)

Any attempt to understand the effects of unemployment on these tens of thousands of young Australians must therefore take into consideration that they are adolescents. Their social circumstances will have some effect in determining the outcome of the developmental processes which occur in this phase of life, and on what sort of adults they will become.

Research There is an astonishing lack of research into the mental health of young people who experience long term unemployment, although this aspect is often referred to in sociological studies.6 8 12
It is possible to make out a prima facie case that unemployment is associated with poor mental health from a number of isolated studies-
Juvenile delinquency in South Australia was associated with unemployed status of offenders and offenders' parents.4
The rate of attempted suicide in unemployed persons in a large Victorian country town was twelve times the average area rate.7
In Blacktown Municipality of NSW, it was estimated that 30-40 per cent of people attempting suicide were unemployed.9
Of 15-24-year-olds who were treated for the first time by the Mental Health Authority (Victoria) and who were unemployed, 11 per cent were diagnosed as alcoholic.1
The majority of 15,000 people under 25 years, estimated to be homeless in Melbourne in 1978, were said to be unemployed.10
Unemployed persons reported more respiratory illnesses, more migraines, more blackouts and more irritability than employed persons in a South Australian study.8
Twenty one per cent of Community Youth Support System, and 35 per cent of Commonwealth Employment Service clients reported 'often feeling depressed'.6
None of these studies assesses personal mental health adequately. Nor do they decide between cause and effect.
The unemployed individual What happens to young people who cannot get work? What do they feel?

My clinical work brings me into contact with many adolescents who cannot find work. A dozen of these I have interviewed regularly over a period of one to three years in each case. I would like to describe what I have observed.

They all started their search for employment on leaving school with confidence and optimism. As successive attempts to find a job proved fruitless, they got angry. They reckoned they had been deceived by school and, when their friends found work (often through the personal influence of parents) they felt unfairly treated. Still they showed courage to go on applying for jobs, some over a hundred times. 'It was like', said one, 'having each morning to climb into the ring with Muhammad Ali knowing that . . . well . . . boom'.
* One third of unemployed people are adolescent.
This paper is based on one delivered at the foundation meeting of the Australian Association for Adolescent Health in Sydney, November 1978.

Suddenly, they felt let down-powerless to do anything about their situation, impotent in the face of seemingly endless rejections of their offered services. Overton has captured this feeling in his cartoons, reproduced here by kind permission of the editor of Nation Review.

The unemployed persons had little spare cash and could not afford to keep up socially with his or her friends. They parted company- a further blow to the self esteem of the unemployed person. Now, instead of going out and enjoying social activities, the jobless person sat around home all day watching television (often quite oblivious to the programme content), bored, lonely and frustrated. At this stage some became very depressed and this was in marked contrast to their earlier and normal selves. One tried to kill himself, several others started abusing drugs and alcohol apparently to escape feelings of despair.

This phase lasted several months before contact was begun with others in a similar position-often met as drinking companions. They then linked up with other unemployed and a happier period began. Activities were enjoyed again and television was eschewed. But I had noticed a change in the personalities of the people I was seeing. In place of those personal aspirations for their future which they had previously cherished, they now talked about having new ideas and personal philosophies. These, it seemed to me, did not have much to do with their own unique personal qualities or experiences but were, rather, products of their new group experiences-with other long-term unemployed persons. However they enabled the person to take a renewed interest in life.

The first phases of anger and despair were reactions to the experiences of rejection. Obtaining work brought a return to normal mental health. However once the group phase had settled in, changes were difficult to reverse. The young person appeared to lose interest in working, or if work were obtained, to lack any enthusiastic commitment, tire quickly of it, and hanker for return to jobless status.
I want to look more closely at why this might be so.
Unemployment and the developmental processes of adolescence

In adolescence, the two major psychosocial tasks are the establishment of independence and the consolidation of a sense of personal identity. It should be clear that unemployment can cut directly across the accomplishment of both of these tasks.

Independence The school child is dependent on parents (or guardians) for food and shelter. It is made clear to him or her that ultimately these commodities will have to be obtained independently. This independence is a basis for acceptance as an adult. However the jobless adolescent must turn from the parents to the State for the money to buy the necessities of life. The alternatives are to remain dependent on parents in some way, or to engage in crime.

Dependency on the State for 'charity' is not considered by our society to be an acceptable demonstration of adult capacity, it suggests that the dependant for instance, could not support a family. Furthermore it is considered a shameful situation not to be able to exchange labour for money. This is reinforced by the demands of the State that the unemployed must register as dependant and must submit to inspection of his or her private activities. The unemployed young person is consequently labelled as a shamed person. It should not be forgotten that his or her parents share the same sense of shame and, for some fathers particularly, this is a situation very hard for them to accept and may result in tremendous conflict with their children.
* Despite unemployment being the major social phenomenon of the past five years, there has been negligible research into its effects on mental health.
* The inability to demonstrate a capacity to support oneself independently is a shameful experience for young people.
Identity

As a group of individuals who are disallowed full social acceptance, the unemployed group becomes stigmatized. They are then identified, by outsiders, in terms of stereotypes. The stereotype of the 'dole bludger' is familiar enough. Others are 'aggressive rebels against society' or 'a moral cancer in the community' or the paternalistic 'problem kids who need saving from themselves'. Of course, these sterotypes represent projections onto the group by the outsiders and have little basis in the actual individuals who make up the group.5

Unfortunately it appears likely that these very stereotypes are used in bonding the individuals in the group. All, as individuals, felt impotent. The group acceptance provides strength by increasing the individual's self esteem. In order for this to happen, personal aspirations are given up and group ideals replace them.

These ideals are elaborations of the common stereotypes but, in order to regain power and overcome the sense of impotence the values inherent in the stereotypes are inverted. Work becomes self-debasement, poverty a virtue, rags a fashion. To maintain group acceptance some at least of these group values need to be retained and therefore the person may find himself in a dilemma when work is offered.

On the one hand, work offers the possibility of acceptance into the wider world of adults. On the other, it means giving up the comfortable acceptance of the group which has nourished a wounded self esteem. To take the first alternative invites the possibility of further rejections, like those previously experienced, with no sure knowledge that, having turned one's back on the group, one will be accepted back if the need arises.

The shaming experiences and the new ideals seem to become fixed in a personal identity. This may be seen as an essentially negative identity based on what, for our society, might be considered negative qualities and unpleasant feelings.
Social effects of group bonding

Of course, this whole question is open to politico-sociological analysis. One can interpret the situation as a good thing or a bad thing, depending on one's own notions about personal and social interactions and change.

There are obvious social possibilities which ought to be briefly considered. For instance, there is, by virtue of the bonding inherent in groups, the power to create opposition to existing social structures. The group processes are themselves vulnerable to manipulation (as Freud pointed out 60 years ago), by outsiders. Such possibilities ought not to be considered farfetched. Countries which share with Australia the highest rate of youth unemployment in the western world-Italy and Britain-have both experienced violent rioting with extreme political action undertaken by groups involving unemployed young people.
Women

The position of women in relation to unemployment presents special problems which have not yet been clearly defined. While it is generally accepted that women have as much right to work as men and to receive equivalent remuneration, in practice this is not yet the case. Furthermore, it is often stated that women should keep out of the work force in the present difficult employment situation. What effect these opposing forces have on young women seeking work from school is not known.

Bearing in mind the high and rising rate of attempted suicide in young females,2 the high incidence of depressive disorders in women compared with men, the recent increased incidence of failed marriages,11 it might be argued that women are seeking to escape the competition for jobs and the conflicting attitudes about their place in the work force, by contracting early unhappy and unsuccessful marriages.
Conclusion

Lack of available research studies has led me to utilize my own clinical observations and to proffer a number of hypotheses about what happens, psychologically, to adolescents who cannot find employment. I am conscious of the limitations of such a speculative appraisal. Nevertheless; I do not think my arguments about the effects of unemployment on the mental health of young people are in major disagreement with the scattered information that has appeared in the literature relevant to the Australian scene.

Of the hypotheses regarding the processes involved, I think these remain to be tested. I feel that failure to analyze the major issues will result in continuing cost to our society. That, so far, this major social phenomenon has largely escaped careful psychological, social and political analysis is in itself a curious matter. In a culture based, as ours is, on paternal lineage, perhaps we underestimate the hostility engendered in the older generations by the potential of the young.
It was Laius, the father, who left his son, Oedipus, exposed to die as an infant.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this debate on the first reading of a money Bill I shall talk for a few minutes tonight about what will be one of the important issues we will all face during the next five or ten years.
—Old age, Senator?

—For you, Senator; not for me. Australia is involved in what could be called the great tax sharing debate. Essentially this is a political argument and, as it applies to governments, it is not party political. It is obvious that different parties will tackle the argument in different ways and come up with different solutions to it, but the problem will still be there whatever solutions might be presented. The plea I make in this brief speech is for a breadth of vision when looking at the whole range of problems and not looking at one or two isolated aspects of taxation with respect to the needs of the various States.

SPEECH.PARA: The argument is not what it used to be. Formerly the argument was about how much the States in aggregate were getting from the Commonwealth Government as part of the share of personal income tax. That matter seems to have been satisfactorily resolved. The argument now is rather about how the individual States carve up the amount of money available. It is a very serious matter. All the signs at the moment are that the argument will get worse and embroil all of us. It will get worse for two reasons. Firstly, there is the economic decline in the principal manufacturing State of Australia, that is the economic decline in Victoria. Its tax base is diminishing or failing to grow from its own internal sources. Secondly, there is the contrast of the resource-rich States going ahead. These two factors are placing demands on the available funds because both groups feel they need more. One group feels it needs more because the inefficient industry is demanding more and more support whereas the other group of States-the resource-rich States-feel that they need more to develop the export earning industries which will produce the funds for the nation to grow.

The origins of this argument, of course, go back to 1942 when the uniform income tax Act was introduced. That Act provided an agreed formula for the distribution by the Commonwealth to the six States which existed at the time. This distribution formula was not sensitive enough and those States which had a small tax base to fall back on to supplement their income were falling behind the other States in the Commonwealth which had a larger tax base within their boundaries and so the Commonwealth Grants Commission was set up. The purpose of the Grants Commission quite simply was not to provide equivalent standards of living between the six Australian States but to raise those States that were behind to a very basic agreed level. I return to the point that under the tax formula there was an unequal distribution of funds to the several States. It is true that those States that paid the most tax gained less than they paid from the Commonwealth.

Some figures currently being circulated by the Victorian Treasury show that Victoria paid the highest tax per person in the Commonwealth. In 1979-80 it was an amount of $1,100 per head. Queensland paid the lowest amount of tax last year of $890 a head. But Victoria received only $318 per person from the Commonwealth as against $430 for every person in Queensland. That is a rather specious argument for a whole variety of reasons. It happens to be one of the principles of all governments that they do not return taxation to those people who contribute most. If that were true, the benefits and the discounts that were available to high income earners would exceed those that were available to low income earners. Of course, the fuel tax is a very good example. We all pay a great deal more collectively to Consolidated Revenue in excise duty on fuel than the Commonwealth Government spends on road grants.

When Victoria looks at this matter it gets a bit upset. As I will show later, this is because it is taking a very limited view of the situation. Victoria looks at the royalty payments that Queensland and Western Australia are earning and, in the case of Queensland, at the earnings from rail freights, and Victoria feels that it has been quite disadvantaged.

But that is only half the argument. Victoria fails to take into account the effect of transfer payments which accrue under the tariff programs that exist for Australia. These are quite huge and, most importantly, they are very unequally applied to the States. For example, the tariffs for every person living in Victoria are equivalent to $430 a head, yet in Queensland they amount to only $123. Putting it another way, I think the figure I saw last week in one of the newspapers in relation to payments made to people working in the motor industry was $15,000 a worker. Most of the workers in the motor industry happen to be in Victoria, with secondary involvement in New South Wales and South Australia. That is a very substantial payment to the community and it is in addition to the payments made by the Commonwealth in return for income tax disbursements to the States.

One of the interesting consequences of all of this is that in the various economic recessions we have had since the Second World War those States which enjoy the highest level of tariff protection as compared with those which have the lowest level, show a marked difference in the unemployment figures. Those States which have the highest unemployment are those which have the lowest recourse to tariff protection and vice versa. Of course, this is seen in the analysis of average incomes for the residents of the various States. This is a very important point to bear in mind. Despite this, when the Grants Commission looks at the several Australian States, it makes an award to Queensland despite the fact that more money is paid to Queensland than to Victoria under the income tax sharing scheme. That rather refutes the validity of the Victorian claim.

The consequences of this high tariff protection, of course, have led Victoria into the problem of a declining industrial virility at present because Victoria has been denied the natural competition of the market place. It has also led to the advancement of Queensland and Western Australia because they were denied the industrial development of the south and they had to turn to more export orientated industries. They have been very successful in that. The work force in Queensland went up by 4.4 per cent in 1979-80 whereas there was an increase of 1.8 per cent in Victoria for the same period.

At the same time, the needs of Queensland are quite different to the needs of Victoria. So one can validate the claim for more money from the tax disbursements than it is getting. Queensland is Australia's most decentralised State. The last figures I was able to obtain are for the year ending 30 June 1976. Only 48.4 per cent of the Queensland population resided in urban centres of more than 100,000 persons compared with a nation-wide average of 64.5 per cent. Of Queensland's population, 31.7 per cent lived in urban centres of between 1,000 and 99,999 persons compared with 24.5 per cent throughout the whole country and 19.8 per cent resided in rural areas compared with 14 per cent throughout Australia.

The provision of services to a highly decentralised population creates problems which are not faced in highly urbanised societies. The magnitude of these problems is evident when it is remembered that these higher costs must be shared by a significantly smaller tax base-a much smaller population-than exists to carry the burden of government services in parts of New South Wales and Victoria. One finds additional problems when one looks at the age distribution within the State. In Queensland, 43.8 per cent of the population is in the 0 to 18 years age bracket and over 65 years of age. This is the second highest percentage of the six States of what can be regarded as those outside the 19 to 64 years productive age group. The provision of services for the young in the form of full-time education and services for the elderly are both costly undertakings, and this places a considerable financial burden on the rest of the population.

The industry employment statistics amplify further problems facing Queensland. Of the employed population, 9.7 per cent are engaged in primary industry, by far the highest figure and well above the Australia-wide average of 7.1 per cent. However, only 13.9 per cent of Queenslanders are employed in manufacturing compared with 24.2 per cent in Victoria, 20.9 per cent in New South Wales and 20.8 per cent in South Australia. Let us look at the break up of those figures in relation to those employed in the manufacturing industry. SPEECH.PARA: This is a serious matter for two reasons. Most people do not recognise the transfer payments which tariffs occasion. Hence, there are ill-formed opinions about the inadequacies of the distribution of tax when it is viewed purely on an income tax distribution basis. Secondly, the tariffs lead to inefficient industries as we see in Victoria today. The motor car industry in Australia is a classic example. It means that there is a higher cost of doing business within Australia. That would be all right if we lived in isolation and if everything kept pace with everything else, but it does not. The cost of tariff protection is an additional cost for our exports, and it is very important to us. We do not live by taking in one another's washing. We live and grow by our export earnings. The country cannot develop if it does not earn money from abroad. So resource development and the export industries are absolutely crucial to us. We should have a good hard look at the effect of tariff protection on the Australian economy.

The effect of all of this is that it inhibits and retards resource development. Queensland, Western Australia and, I hope, South Australia and Tasmania, by developing resources, help the whole of the Australian community with their export earnings. At the same time, of course, States such as Queensland and Western Australia are helping themselves to catch up to a reasonable standard of living, the standard of living which has been enjoyed by the southern States for so many generations. Queensland is doing that by virtue of its mining royalties and its rail freights. The royalties are perfectly fair and accepted. They are perfectly legal from a constitutional point of view. The authority is vested in the State to levy these charges. These charges in Queensland, I am happy to say, are levied at a rate which the market will bear. The rail freights are an issue for Queensland's creative thinking. Queensland is making a profit-quite unashamedly-out of mineral rail freights. That is of benefit to the whole of the Australian community. Revenue from rail freights has increased from $12m in 1960 to $190m in 1980. The gross revenue from the railways has increased to approximately $353m in 1980. Out of this income, Queensland has been able to develop and to upgrade the rail system, which is very important in a large and decentralised State. It has enabled industrial development to take place through the building of rolling stock with its benefits of employment and the distribution of funds throughout Australia. It has enabled the subsidisation of passenger services to take place-in aggregate, $103m last year for the city and country passenger services and for the freight services throughout the State. It is important that this is done because if we did not earn revenue from the freighting of our minerals, there would be a charge against consolidated revenue, in one form or another, and the public would have to pay. This way the public does not pay; the industry pays.

I should like to return to my original theme; the argument that we will face through the next five to ten years is the argument over the level of disbursements of personal income tax by the Commonwealth to the States. It is a very emotional issue. I think the temperature will rise very considerably as the balance within the Australian economy changes. It is not a simple argument. It needs to be understood in all its complexity and a balanced approach needs to be taken so that fairness shall prevail. If that happens, the whole Australian community can benefit because we can grow and develop the money from our export earnings which we need so much.
