TALK.START.PARA: —I take advantage of the first reading debate on these money Bills tonight to raise with the Government a matter which I think is scandalous and which exists all over Victoria. I refer to dental disease. So far as I can ascertain from my observations and from talking to people all over Victoria, we have a raging epidemic of dental disease in Victoria and neither the State Government nor the Federal Government will do anything about it. That may be, of course, because it is affecting mainly those who have no vote. It is affecting children, the aged and the handicapped who are in institutions. By far the most horrifying point of view, because of the inference it has for the future, is that it is the children of Victoria who are sick and suffering and who have a very dismal future because of this illness.

SPEECH.PARA: I have had reports from the country and from the city. I have had them from middle class suburbs in the east of Melbourne and from the working class suburbs in the north of Melbourne. Everywhere there is a raging epidemic of tooth decay and tooth loss. In December 1980, a school principal in Northcote reported that many children's teeth were rotting away. On closer examination, he said that 50 per cent of children in the preps and in grade 1 were in dire need of dental work. In October 1980, the principal of the Heidelberg Primary School reported that 50 per cent of his prep and grade 1 children were in dire need of dental treatment. That was the case in only the first two classes of those primary schools.

Reports were made to the Nunawading and Box Hill councils about the appalling state of children's teeth. The Camberwell City Council was advised of the deep concern expressed by a visiting dentist at a brush-in at a local school because of the large number of children whose first teeth were seriously decayed. The headmaster of a primary school of 356 pupils in Ballarat, Victoria, did a survey of those 356 pupils and found that over 60 children had complained of toothache in the previous three or four weeks, including children from each of the 12 grades; that over 60 children had been identified as needing urgent dental work, including children from each of the 12 grades; and that over 70 children had been identified as having very poor oral hygiene. That was despite no official inspection having been made, and the above numbers represented obvious attention needed. There would, of course, be more children than that number requiring attention. The problem is not new; that is the appalling aspect. It is not as though suddenly the children of Victoria have developed badly decayed teeth and badly diseased mouths. This has been going on for a considerable number of years and nothing has been done.

The very real problem that exists-I suspect it exists all over Australia although I have experience only of Victoria-was recognised by the Whitlam Government. That Government, in its 1975-76 Budget, allocated $26.4m towards achieving the goal of free dental treatment for all primary school children by 1982. That was a great goal and would have been a wonderful achievement. The present Government, in 1975-76, reduced that $26.4m to $24m and in 1980-81 has made available only $23.3m. Six years later, after all the inflationary increases that have come about because of this Government's policies, we have less money to spend on dental care than we had in 1975-76 and we have no goal. The amount allocated in 1975-76 was reduced when the Fraser Government took power. In 1976-77 it reduced that amount even further. In 1976 the Fraser Government said that it planned to provide a dental service to all primary school children by 1985. There is not one sign of that planned dental service and the dental health of the children of Australia is worse than it ever was and is getting worse still.

The scheme to provide a dental service for all primary school children depended on dental therapists being trained. In 1976 it was estimated that we needed 2,300 therapists to provide a free dental service for all primary school children. In 1976 only 944 of those 2,300 had been trained. The expenditure on the training of therapists has been almost halved. No more facilities have been built. The scheme has not been expanded. So in 1981, five years after the Fraser Government said that it had a goal of a dental service for all primary school children by 1985, Victoria has the lowest percentage in Australia of children covered by a dental scheme and appalling dental health.

It is not just the primary school children who are in bad need of dentists and of dental care. In 1976 the dental advisory committee to the Minister for Health in Victoria reported that the state of dental health in Victoria was still deplorable. It had previously reported in 1969 and nothing had been done in the intervening years. This study pointed out that particular groups were in great need of dental assistance. Those groups were the frail aged, handicapped children, disadvantaged school children and the populations of small towns. The results of the survey confirmed the need for more dentists to improve the deplorable state of dental health in Victoria and in addition highlighted the need for a comprehensive dental health survey in Victoria, for the rational development of dental care services in Victoria and for better education of dentists to cope with the special dental health problems of disadvantaged groups. Nothing has been done.

The survey found that in 1976 and, as I said earlier, in 1969 there were about 300,000 people in Victoria over the age of 65 years; and no one knew what their state of dental health was. A small pilot study was done of 100 aged people visiting or confined in a geriatric institution. It was found that 97 said that they seldom visited a dentist and over 25 said that they could not remember when they last visited one. A high proportion of the patients did not know where their nearest dentist was located. Seventy-two said that they could not manage public transport before entering hospital and one-third of those would have no one to assist them to visit a dentist when they left the hospital.

More than half the group said that they had had their teeth extracted more than 20 years ago and three had neither natural teeth nor dentures. More than half claimed that their dentures were more than 10 years old and about one-third thought they needed new dentures. The examiners considered that two-thirds of the dentures were poorly cleaned and that about one-third were encrusted with deposits of calculus. About two-thirds of the patients with dentures needed new dentures or repairs to their dentures. Many of the patients who had retained some natural teeth had severe disease and/or tooth decay. Often such patients were not aware of any disease processes occurring in their mouths. Some urgently required treatment for dental decay. There were not enough trained dental personnel at the institution to give adequate care to sufficient numbers of the patients in need. That was in 1969 and it was repeated in 1976.

Last year in Victoria a similar survey was done and the same people said that, if anything, the situation had got worse and that nobody seemed to care whether aged people, frail or not, received adequate dental care. There are no additional dentists in Victoria but there is a greater population. There are no additional trained dental personnel. There are no additional dental clinics. That sort of situation cannot help the health of aged people. It cannot help them if they cannot eat properly, if they cannot eat proper food and if they are in pain and their mouths are ulcerated.

Another group that these people in Victoria were concerned about was handicapped children. If, as I have suggested, the dental health of healthy children, of children who are not in institutions or of children who are not physically handicapped is bad, then the dental care of handicapped children in Victoria is appalling. There is very little hope that they will get any dental care at all. There are more than 20,000 handicapped children in Victoria and about half of them are severely handicapped. The handicaps include cerebral palsy, spina bifida, mental retardation, chronic disease, deafness, blindness and some congenital conditions. The dental disorders of the handicapped are more severe, more difficult to treat and frequently more prevalent than those of the normal population. Oral hygiene procedures are far more difficult to carry out on the handicapped and consequently gum disorders are more severe there than they are in the normal population.

The preliminary findings of all these surveys are that handicapped children suffer from much untreated dental disease, including decayed teeth, gum disorders and irregular teeth. The existing dental services, through both government and voluntary agencies, are hopelessly inadequate and overloaded. There are few preventive dental care programs operating within institutions. A number of institutions have routine dental facilities but cannot get either voluntary or salaried staff. Special dental facilities for treating handicapped patients are inadequate; that is, patients frequently require anaesthesia, yet such facilities are available at only a few centres where waiting lists are already very long. Education of more dentists in the special procedures of caring for the handicapped is urgently needed. There is a need for special education for dentists.
Debate interrupted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have never spoken before in this chamber on the subject of dental health, but I am moved to reflect on a few aspects of it, with no reference at all to any previous debate tonight. The Federal Government has been involved in funding dental health for some eight or nine years now-I am not sure for how long-and the current annual payment through the school dental services would run in excess of $20m. I think it is a worthwhile and laudable service insofar as it provides a form of treatment that it is necessary to deliver. I have some thoughts on whether the Government is moving to supply that service in the most cost-effective way, but that is not a matter I am prepared to discuss tonight because we are debating the adjournment of the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: The point I would like to get across with great firmness to the Senate is that the school dental service, or any service of that nature, is a reparative service. It is a service that is provided after disease has occurred, and in that sense it is wrong because dental disease is preventable. Dental disease is one disease that need not occur in the human race, and that has been known for 20 or 30 years. The classic means of prevention on a public health scale, of course, is through the application of fluoride to drinking water. If we do not like that, we can have recourse to dietary control measures, the restriction-not the elimination but the restriction-of refined carbohydrates in the diet being one of the methods.

It is interesting to look at the statistics on dentists' children. Those statistics show that some 20 or 30 years ago their caries experience was negligible. My own four children went through to adult life without having any caries experience. Four times 32 teeth without caries is not a bad record. The important thing about dentists' children is not that they are all following one regime of caries control or caries prevention; they are following a variety of schemes. The important point is that caries can be prevented from occurring and, rather than coming in after the ravages of the disease, that should be the task of the Government. I think that is a most important point for the Senate to understand, and it relates to all the health programs in which we become involved. For goodness sake, let us put a little more emphasis on the prevention of disease, let us not try just to repair its ravages.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 10.34 p.m.
